reviews.review:
Postrio was fantastic!  They took great care of me and my wife when celebrating her birthday!

I highly recommend the meatloaf!

Service was simply incredible and well deserving of the five stars.  Worth it all the way around and a genuine find in the Venetian!

WAY TO GO WOLFGANG!

To paraphrase Lloyd Bentsen, I know St Mark's Square. And you Sir, are no St Mark's Square. 

But pretty close.

Postrio is a restaurant within tne Wolfgang Puck empire; from LA to takeshitma st in Tokyo. I'd like to say it's one of his more formal ones but those restaurant days are happily long gone.

It's situated within the faux st marks square in the massive shopping precinct of the Venetian. There's an internal, lesser used restaurant area and a lovely open veranda area and bar,looking onto the square and the Batali/ Bastianich complex across the way.

With the outside area, you have the advantage of hearing the musicians playing Neapolitan classics ( in Venice?) and enjoying the general atmosphere under the faux blue skies. Best thing is shouting at the mimes, knowing they can't shout back.  


  We've been there twice, the first time having life changing truffles gnocchi. Sadly, on this visit, they were gone, but pleasantly replaced by similar ones filled with prime rib. Superb, but portions which would never be doled out by any Italian mama I know. Small would be a generous description. Also had the mushroom fettucine which was good.

Ended with a créme burl which was superb.  

A good culinary experience but I do believe they don't need to try experimenting with nouvelle cuisine portions, especially in Vegas. 

They do offer regular 20% discounts for hote
 Guests and elsewhere as well.

Great location and view within St. Mark's Square in the Shoppes at the Venetian, and I love that it has cozier, elegant "inside" dining as well as faux al fresco patio dining.  We were given an "outside" table, next to the bar.  

The menu looked good, and we had a large party so we ordered lots to sample.  I started with the Asparagus soup with Maine crab and black pepper creme fraiche.  It was excellent.   The chicken spring rolls were quite good - crispy, sweet and complex.  Unfortunately, it was all downhill from there.  I went pretty basic for my meal - spaghetti and meatballs.  I felt this dish was uninspired and pedestrian.  The meatballs were undersized and had a very soft texture which did not sit well with me.  The pizzas were better than average, but we more than once looked longingly across the square at Ottos which specializes in pizza.  The rigatoni with fennel sausage bolognese was a step above the other main dishes.  

One last note - the wine was decent.  The waiter recommended a bottle of syrah that was a fairly impressive syrah, and very modestly priced.  

Overall, I was expecting more from this restaurant.

This was a nice restaurant.  We decided to eat inside because the musical trio playing outside was so loud, even the hostess said she cant bare it!  I had a fall special, the pumpkin tortellini which was very good, but you only got 6 pieces for $21.  Meatloaf was ok and the pizza was good.  Serve was attentive and there when we needed him.
The lobster sandwich here is still one of the best I've had. They also have really good oysters.
Not a good place for a group of nine.  Had to send one of guest's plate back twice - undercooked, items listed on the menu were not available, food was plain ... Not worth $750.

Service = 2 stars 
Food = 2 stars 
Atmosphere = 2 stars 

Visited Postrio for a bachelorette party dinner. The best thing I can say about the meal was that we were seated promptly. After that everything went downhill. For some reason it felt like our party was written off immediately after we sat down. We had 3 servers before the meal even came out of the kitchen and when the food did come out it was impossible to get a waiter's attention. 

I was expecting great food from a Wolf Gang Puck restaurant but was surprised to taste a rather bland pasta aka the Spaghettini Pasta w/ meatballs. The tomato sauce was not to my liking (there was no flavor) and the meatballs were red inside also, with no flavor. My fellow diners were not that impressed with their food either. The best dish at the table seemed to be the duck.  Being a foodie I was sad to find the best part of the meal was in a glass of wine.  

The restaurant is situated in the open in the middle of the Venetian Shopping Gallery. Definitely not a place to be romantic. Would have been good for our party if the service and food had tasted better. As there are quite a few options in Las Vegas for dining, I can't say that I would return after our lackluster experience.
I will forever dream of that $60 summer truffle risotto....my god, it was glorious.

Good food and great ambience. A bit on the pricey side but otherwise tastes excellent. It's a great place to bring a date with the music playing in the background. For being in vegas and it's location it's not too bad.

I had duck and my boyfriend had seared tuna. We were with a group of about 15 of us, Dinner was fine but a bit pricey for what it was. The house made chocolates that they brought out were absolutely a dream though!

Postrio. Wolfgang Puck. One of these is known by name everywhere, the other in vegas.

Wolfgang puck does not mess around with his restaurants. When it comes to location and style, this location delivers and so does the food.

To say we had an amazing meal here, would be giving well deserved credit to it being, well...an amazing meal. We elected to eat here since we had a 20% off coupon set up with the hotel (we're jews, what can I say haha).  However, what did that 20% not include? Drinks. 

Needless to say, I love moscato and they have great moscato. Along with that, our salads were very interesting and artfully designed. The gorgonzola was a bit disgusting, but I think that might be personal preference.

So, the porcini mushroom ravioli? Amazing. Seriously good stuff.  I'd suggest everyone to try it. I believe bass was on the menu too, which I had, and was equally excellent.

Honestly, I don't know what to say other than that this is a must to get some food at, even if it is fairly expensive.

I was a bit torn on whether or not to say that this place has outdoor seating due to the fact that it's inside the Grand Canal Shoppes at the Venetian, which is spectacularly themed to look like St. Mark's Square in Venice. We sat on the "patio" and even saw some pigeons walking about! 

    I had a chopped vegetable salad, which was actually pretty good and managed to fill me up. Nice place to grab a bite and people-watch in Vegas!

Don't let the fact that Wolfgang puck owns it tempt you in any way. Completely unmemorable. I can't say it was good, nor was it bad. Too many other good places to eat. The highlight was seeing Sigfried and Roy at the next table.
The 4 cheese ravioli was great but the service was awful. The menu items were pretty pricey as well.

Wolfgang Puck can do no wrong. My boyfriend and I ate here for lunch one day and pretty much had the best meals of our lives. We ordered a $25 pitcher of the red wine sangria, which was more than enough, but of course we finished it all! I had a veggie pizza with toppings like goat cheese, butternut squash, zucchini, eggplant, tomatoes, and squash blossoms. My boyfriend had the lobster club sandwich. The whole meal at Postrio basically consisted of eating and saying "Oh. My. God." in between bites/drinks. You will have a foodgasm for sure.
The food was amazing! The service impeccable! Atmosphere was wonderful! This was a great dinner all around! One of our new favorites!!

For a Wolfgang Puck restaurant, I was not impressed. The food was eeeeh. I dined with a party of twelve people and everyone pretty much had the same experience as I did. The place was definitely fine dining. You can tell by the decor. I am pretty sure this place has a loyal following. I regret to say that the cuisine did not leave much of an impression.

One of the things I love about Las Vegas, and is one of the things rarely brought to attention when mentioning Vegas, is their fixation with designing interiors made to look like exteriors. Case in point - The Venetian. Everyone knows about the statues and the carefully painted walls of sky, but it's also nice that they coordinate their businesses to go with the outdoor theme indoors. Other case in point - Postrio (inside The Venetian). 

My girls took me here for a pre-bachelorette festivities dinner. My first thought on in this place was "Argh, another Italian place? Ok, just smile and pretend to like it." My second thought was, "Oh cool, they've got sleek, modern-looking planters and an "outdoor" patio in front of the "inside" inside restaurant."

I kicked off the meal with a glass of Sangria, pleasant, but not much kick and I've definitely had better (my fave is Fresca in San Francisco). I ordered the Porcini Mushroom Ravioli and a side of asparagus, I hadn't eaten since breakfast and thought the ravioli wouldn't be enough. 

The ravioli skin was tender and the savory sauce marinated beautifully with it. I gave my friend a taste, and she liked it so much, she kept dipping her bread in it! 

The asparagus was presented with two types - the traditional green and also, white. Sauteed asparagus seems a hard one to master, and though the dish was better than average, I'd suggest cooking longer as the outside was a bit chewier than I liked. 

After polishing off my meal, which would have been filling enough with just the ravioli, I had a bite of my friend's Spaghettini Pasta...it was phenomenal for just noodles and marinara! I literally had one bite, as I was very full already, but that spaghetti was likely the best spaghetti I've ever had.

The prices are steep for what you get, but for special occasions or for moments of 'I just feel like eating somewhere nice', this is the place to go.

Ahhh, Postrio!  My husband treated me several years ago to a wonderful meal at this Venetian hotel/St. Mark's Square restaurant, and it was the highlight of our trip.  We have returned since to Vegas but hadn't had the occasion to visit Postrio again.  We have often talked about how wonderful that first visit was; the waitress was especially accommodating in making recommendations and the food was magnificent.

Guess what?  This time was no exception!  We chose Postrio for a small business group dinner and were so impressed.  Appetizers we chose were crab cakes, the cheese/honeycomb/quince/pink lady apple/candied pecans, etc. plate, and the sausage trio.  All were excellent.  Our server, Erin, was exceptional in describing the main courses avalable, and as it was late my husband and two others chose the salmon.  All remarked on how tender and flavorful this meal was.  I have never tasted duck, having been told that it is very greasy.  Again, Erin's description had me intrigued, so I tried their special.  Such a wonderful dish!  

Another review mentions the chocolate beignets-if you love chocolate and don't want too sweet a dessert, this is the one for you!  Another in our party requested creme brulee (though it is not on the menu) and the chef made an especially lovely one with fresh berries.

It is not too fine a point to make that one member in our party was about an hour late.  Erin also had two large parties of wedding guests while we were dining - but we were never made to feel rushed or in any way less important.  I guarantee everyone was well-served.

We are definitely comfortable sharing this gem with our friends and business acquaintances.  Afterward, a trio of musicians treated guests to a lovely concert on the stage in St. Mark's Square, just beyond Postrio's "outdoor" dining area (we had eaten inside the restaurant itself).  

In all, another wonderful experience, and we look forward to returning soon!

Stopped in here for lunch the other day in between work meetings at the Venetian. I stopped here because it has a nice open bar area and I can people watch. I assumed the food would be good since it is associated with a celebrity chef. I was not disappointed at all. The people watching was fantastic (chick in camo pants that had attached fluffy white feathers at the bottom of the pantleg) and the hamburger was supreme. I ordered the hamburger that is served with a red onion marmalade - I could eat that marmalade every day it is so good. The rest of the menu looked very interesting so I would definitely go back for more.

I only ate TWICE in Vegas.

Not because I was on a mission to fit into my dresses. Not because I wasn't hungry. WHY THEN?

Because like always, we had NO time. haha. 

I was SO happy we got to roam around and tour at least one hotel. We picked the right spot. 

Margaritas were to DIE for. You could taste the fresh squeezed lime juice.

Bruschetta was perfection. $7 for about 2 small toasted crostini's and tomatoes is steep but HEY its Vegas!

Tomato soup was soooo good. I thought of Lily L b/c she always orders soup so I had to give this one a try. 

Soft Shell Crab sandwich has got to be the BEST thing ever!! So filling and delicious! Too bad I could only handle half of a half! 

Margherita pizza was the only thing that didn't blow me away. It was very oily. I was going to award 5 stars but it was very normal food that tasted very good in VEGAS. For the price, I could have gone to the best restaurant in SJ and had my world rocked.

Had Michael as our server, HORRIBLE service.

Our treatment versus others around us was atrocious.  After ordering and chatting up with my friend she pointed to tables around us.  I noticed he was putting bread baskets down on tables and when I asked for ours he said it was available during request.  A couple sat down after us and I overheard him offer them a bread basket, then he offered it to other tables that sat down.  

We bought a bottle of wine like we usually do and he was never around to refill our drinks, I got up once to do it myself and a busperson came over to do it for me.  I took care of him since Michael wasn't around.

And then another thing I overheard behind me, he told them the two specials that weren't on the menu.  Something about lobster and risotto I think, two of my favorite things!  We ended up ordering a filet mignon (alright), new york steak (alright), and the peanut souffle (damn good).  

If you dine here, do NOT risk your dinner experience with Michael as your server.  I still tipped him 20% because that's who I am but it'll be a toss up if you get shitty service or the stand in the middle of the restaurant where they place their order type of service.  Even the two managers on at the time weren't going around asking people how their meals or dining experience was going.  They seemed like an inseparable pair, always going off together and coming back to the podium together.

This restaurant is pretty amazing! Be prepared for the prices, they are a little on the steeper side, but well worth every penny. Great place to celebrate a special occasion or make reservations for a date night with the beau. It's tucked away inside the Venetian Hotel and Casino and although there's several shops and tourists nearby, the restaurant - even when you're sitting "outside" feels super elegant and cozy. The cocktails are great, the food is great, and the service was pretty stellar also!

This was my first visit to a Wolfgang Puck restaurant and perhaps my expectations were a bit too high.  I know that his brand has extended far beyond a size he could reasonably oversee on his own, but I was inspired by a book on food history I read that gave me new appreciation for Puck's early culinary breakthroughs and for contributing to the gourmet pizza trend that began in the 80s.

I started my meal with the trio of house-made sausages served with three mustards and pickled vegetables.  This was a delicious dish, though really a bit too large to be served as a first course.
For my second course, I had to try one of his famous pizzas.  Since it is usually the simpler dishes that allow culinary genius to really shine, I opted for the margerita pizza and was sadly disappointed.  The pizza section of the menu was placed before the entrees, but this was misleading as the pizza was large enough to be an entree.  Now I expect large portions from chains such as the Cheesecake Factory, but here I would have expected quality over quantity and that was not the case.  The ratio of the ingredients was off with everything being dominated by a very thick layer of cheese.  The tomatoes were bland and the crust was a bit soggy under all that cheese.  When I did nibble on the bits of crust around the edge there was none of that amazing flavor you find in better pizzas or even the crusty/chewy combo to be had at places like Settebello.  Sadly, even Lavo has a better margerita pizza last time I checked.  This didn't exhibit any of the charectaristics of a high-end pizza.  My friend ate one piece and I didn't even finish mine.
For my entree, I selected the lobster roll, though after tasting it I think a better description would have been a BLT.  This sandwich was good, but not great.  The bacon dressing used on the sandwich was delicious and the Applewood smoked bacon was tasty, but between the two, overpowered the flavor of the lobster.  The grain bread and arugula was quite nice, but the tomatoes were flavorless and I found that unforgivable.  I work in the restaurant industry here in Vegas and know first hand that there are some amazing tomatoes to be had here.  Serving bland hothouse tomatoes in August is just plain lazy.  The amount of lobster actually in the lobster roll was not generous enough to be considered the main ingredient, though the chunks that were included were tender and delicious.  This was accompanied by a mound of french fries large enough to serve a family of four.  Really.  

For dessert, we shared the chocolate beignets.  The presentation was lovely, with a large quenelle of caramel macchiatto ice cream, a small dish of vanilla dipping sauce and a small pile of chocolate beignets filled with a liquid chocolate center.  This was the one course where the portion size was appropriate.  The ice cream was fabulous - the flavors well balanced, the texture was very creamy and it paired well with the beignets.  The vanilla sauce was thicker than a classic anglaise and just right for adhering to the little doughnuts.  I loved the flavor of the beignets and thought the filling was a great idea, but it wasn't executed very well.  They were quite doughy in the middle- either from being under cooked or simply by putting the liquid ganache in the center while still warm.  Either way this kept the dessert from being as good as it could have been.  

Another disappointment was the service.  Our server was OK, but I felt rushed at several points during the meal.  Yes, my friend and I were doing a lot of talking, but I don't think that keeping our table for under 2 hours for four courses is unreasonable.  Two of the courses were cleared while I was literally still chewing food from my plate. I also would have expected the server to do something about the disappointing pizza.   Either take it off our bill or offer us something else, but when less than two pieces are eaten (between two people) that should be a flag that something is wrong.  In fact at one point after our pizza was cleared, but before our main course, the busser brought the pizza out in a to-go box and put it down on our table.  I wondered just what he wanted us to do with it.  It was too large on a very small table to fit the plates for our next course, so it had to be taken away again.  No problem, neither of us wanted to take it home.

All in all it wasn't a bad meal.  Some of the food was good and I did end up really enjoying my wine, but that isn't enough.  In this competitive food town, not bad, just isn't good enough to bring me back for seconds.

Perfect. Great service, great food, great wine, great food.

The lobster BLT impresses and the corn soup is outstanding.

Full of win.

The first tip I would give for diners at Postrio is to not sit "outside," as they call it.  The inside of the Venetian is exquisite and luxurious and fantastic, but it's not ACTUALLY going to convince you that you're outside, and sitting on the "patio" outside the restaurant left us feeling like we were eating in a mall.  Go sit inside, which looked beautiful and quiet.

The sangria is tasty, but not the best I've ever had.  The cherry margarita was artificial tasting, and while everyone else at our table lauded the pom-ojito, I wasn't a huge fan.  They brought out warm tuscan bread with butter and olive tapenade, which I could have made a meal of all on its own.  I could go for some now, actually...

Our food was kind of give-a-little, take-a-little.  The heirloom tomato caprese salad was easily the best I've ever had, with burrata that is gooey and creamy at room temperature, pesto oil, and a balsamic drizzle.  It was the kind of salad you eat slowly to let every bite spread out on your tongue.  I just wish it was bigger... one lump of burrata, four slices of tomato, $15.  Ouch, Wolfgang.

Two of us got the ribs, which got an "eh" review and came with onion rings that are a dead-ringer (HAR, get it?) for Sonic's.  Not a bad thing; I love Sonic onion rings, I just wouldn't expect to find them at Postrio.  My Mother got the chicken piccata special, which is normally dredged and sauteed, and came deep-fried, which was not mentioned on the menu.  She's not a deep-fried type of person, so little hiccup there.  Dad got the prime ribeye in a cognac mustard sauce with parmesan frites that was all so, so, so delicious, but came out rare when he ordered medium.  

Aunt got the bouillabaisse with seafood tortellini, which were cold, and apparently got hard when reheated.  She complained and was coddled by a manager, who comped her meal and brought her out dessert on the house despite her protests.  Super, super classy.

I was the "big winner" with shrimp pesto pizza with broccolini, sun-dried tomatoes, fresh tomatoes, and something a wee bit spicey that was perfection.  The pizzas are some of the most reasonable things on the menu, and they're huge - our server, Brandy, said 10", but I thought mine was closer to 11" or 12".  It went around the table and I STILL took home a slice and a half.  So much shrimp, so much pesto, so much crust... I'm drooling a wee bit.  

My pizza and the bread easily saved the rating, here.  OH, and dessert.  My aunt's strawberry shortcake was okay, but my cousin got a chocolate cheesecake for her birthday, and "Happy Birthday" was written on the plate in melted chocolate.  It was beautiful and yummy.  I got chocolate beignets filled with molten chocolate, served with caramel ice cream and a vanilla bean dipping sauce.  The doughnuts themselves were a tad salty, but the whole package together was perfect.

The general consensus after dinner was that it was way too pricey for the number of missteps, but the service was impeccable, and there were indeed some very high notes.  I think I'd go back for lunch, or even just for pizza and wine.  (What, you've never had?  It's secretly the world's most perfect combination.  That, or butter and olive tapenade...)
Had an excellent meal here after the phantom show.  What a great evening.  Got both the show tickets and 20% discount for diner at tix 4 tonite.  Sit "outside" for best diner effect.

We had a large party of 13 for a bachelorette party and they were so accommodating! The staff and service was outstanding and impressive. I loved that the restaurant was located in the Venetian by the canal shoppes. It has the open airy feeling of dining outside in Europe! The food was good, and I'm glad the portions were medium sized! My favorite appetizer is the tuna tartare, totally melts in your mouth and the flat bread pizzas. The fried risotto balls and chicken skewers lacked flavor and were least popular. I think that needs to get off the menu! I was adventurous and ordered one of the specials of the day, which was the peking duck. Delicious & creative! Despite our large group, the food came out on queue and we all had a wonderful time!

Wolfgang Puck's establishment at The Venetian meets the standards we've come to associate with his food.  Pizza, pasta and seafood are plentiful and reasonably priced.  Decent bottles of wine can also be had for about $30 a bottle.  Postrio is located conveniently near the main entrance of the Canal Shops maze.

Not bad, but not great. I had the free range chicken, came with kale and a potato puree. The first bite of the chicken I had was delicious! But the more I ate and the closer I got to the bottom, the saltier it got. So I ended up eating about half my dish. Kinda wish I had ordered the salmon instead. 

However, the location is great. Right on the one side of the square surrounded by shops. They were playing music (live) in the square so that was kind of good entertainment. I would recommend this place, maybe just not the chicken.

Dan and Blanche extend a warm invitation to help them celebrate a very special occasion. We are happy to join them and looked forward to having a first time experience at this restaurant. 

Two seating areas of this place, the first being I guess what they would consider outside seating, they call it their patio cafe and bar lounge, however it really is not outside because this place is in the Venetian Grande Canal Shoppes. You feel like you're outside because of the setting within this shopping (I'll call it an upscale Vegas style) mall is all about the Trompe L'oeil, (painted to be realistic) you feel like you're in a Venetian style town complete with the canal waterway, restaurants, shops and yes even a sky. Upon entering and walking through the facade of what is outside, you enter into a very minimalist modern style dining room. 

The menu is American with Asian and Mediterranean influence. But, to be perfectly honest with you... I can't remember what the heck I had for my main course, something Asian like, The dish I remember best was the incredible salad I had before my main course. Yes, it is true, the salad was the star. It seems so simple...Cappressi Salad, but it was not! I don't know how they did it... a couple maybe more, drizzles of fine olive oils, plate dotted with pesto or a sauce, basil based and of course a primo balsamic vinegar along with a dollop of the softest mozzerella and just the right garnish. They actually turned something simple into something extraordinary. I would have been happy with just this salad and a nice Champagne. Nice job.

Our favorite restaurant in Las Vegas.

We've enjoyed this restaurant a couple of times per month for the last couple of years, and several times before that.  It's really like two different restaurants, the "outdoor" more casual portion in Saint Mark's Square, great for people watching and enjoying the entertainment on the nearby stage, and the more upscale and romantic "inside" portion.  Every meal has been delicious, and the service has always been prompt and courteous, even the bussers.  Their filet mignon is perfect, and their pastas are outstanding, especially their spicy Bolognese sauce.  Also, their cocktails are the best we've found anywhere in town, their deserts are always delicious and interesting, and even their bread basket rocks.  We also like that we can visit this strip restaurant without having to walk through a smoky casino.  They have a new head chef, who has been introducing interesting specials, like rabbit and game meats.  We can usually find something disappointing everywhere, but we've never been disappointed by anything at Postrio.  We've enjoyed all Wolfgang Puck restaurants that we've tried, but this is by far our favorite.

I'm not sure whether the word 'Postrio' has a meaning, or whether it is a place. And I'm not sure whether Wolfgang Puck's restaurant knows what it is supposed to be, either.


 Wolfgang Johann Puck is an Austrian celebrity chef, restaurateur, and businessman based in Los Angeles. Postrio, San Francisco, is one of his flagships, and he's replicated it here in Las Vegas. Located on St. Mark's Square in the Grand Canal Shoppes in the Venetian Resort Hotel Casino, the restaurant provides both casual and more formal dining. It offers a menu of seasonal American cuisine with Mediterranean influences, available either in an elegant dining room or a more casual setting on the patio of St. Mark's Square. Luchtime is patio dining only with a restricted menu.


 Puck is a great self publicist whose face is all over his web sites. He has enjoyed undoubted success and his restaurants have had rave reviews. But something has to give when a chef becomes a Brand (it's happening now in GB with Gordon Ramsey). In the case of Postrio, Las Vegas, both food and service have suffered. Postrio is in the top price bracket, so one does not expect ones waiter to be a non-english speaking Mexican, who clears plates whilst ones colleague is still eating. Miserly portions on plates decorated with squiggles of balsamic reduction have never impressed me, and this is what you get here.


 A very comfortable, well situated and attractive place, Postrio is nonetheless not worth the money.


 PS: Can anyone shed any light on the word 'Postrio'?

Came here last Friday night for dinner. We had a 150$ commped dinner and waiter was great.  The oysters fresh, the Kobe rib eye to die for, the Greek salad huge!  Must say the best part of the evening was watching Steve Wynn and Larry king. Made the night fun! Loved sitting out front on the patio people watching also.

Disclosure:  My cousin is a bartender here

Seriously, she makes the best Mai Tais ever!  They're so good the restaurant decided to add her recipe to the drink menu.  Hang out at the bar, a great cast of local characters always find their way in to hang out with the bartenders.

My twin sister and I headed to Vegas for the weekend to celebrate our birthday.  Knowing we had limited time in the city, we did our best to plan for a dinner near our hotel (the Tropicana) and near where our show was (Planet Hollywood).  However, after much searching, we couldn't find anything that in that south part of the strip we'd risk that much money on a dinner for.

It was Saturday night over a hot and busy Vegas weekend, and it was getting pretty late before we had to decide on something.  So, we pulled out our smartphones -- one of us on OpenTable and the other on Yelp.  We agreed on Postrio and drove over.

We could not have been happier.  We were promptly seated in their "outdoor patio" area, and our waiter was quick with everything.  We had ordered the calamari, the herb pappardelle, and the prime rib eye.  Atypically, we skipped on any alcohol, but since we were already drinking for free the whole day out playing in the casinos, we thought we'd save some money on the alcohol (we also had a couple of bottles waiting for us in the hotel).

The pasta was just what I needed -- creamy and thick, yet delicate in flavor, and everything was fresh.  But, next time, I'm ordering the prime rib eye, because that cut of meat was probably the best I've tried in a long time.  Came with potatoes and veggies.  All of the serving sizes were substantial, we came out full.

Now, I recommend doing your research on a place you plan to go to, before you go, because if you don't know what something is on a menu when you get here, and you don't have the balls to ask, then you shouldn't be disappointed when you order it, you get it, and you're not happy with it.  That said, I knew that Wolfgang Puck had a great reputation, his restaurants don't typically find me anything but satisfied, and the reviews on Yelp seemed promising.  I didn't want to order anything I didn't think I knew, so we went with pasta and steak and were extremely satisfied.

Easily used my $20 OpenTable gift certificate, and the restaurant also did a beautiful complimentary birthday tiramisu.  Thanks, Postrio.  We'll be baaaaack!

The food was very good, especially the dessert recommended by several users. We were also able to easily get a reservation on Open Table, and they got us in and out quickly when we told them we were going to a show. Beware that if you are a vegetarian your options are more limited than some Italian restaurants.

My second time at Postrio though it's been a few years since our last visit.  This time we were supposed to be a party of 9 but at the last minute four cancelled out.  The hostess handled the change no problem and we were seated at one of the high tables.  

I went with the asparagus soup for appetizer which was absolutely delicious.  Others went with the grilled chicken skewers which were also delicious.   For the main course I went with the linguine with clams and pancetta which was just awesome.  Another in our party got the salmon and that was one of the best, most flavorful salmon dishes I've ever had.  Not sure what all was in the seasonings, but just delicious.   Another in the party got the Schnitzel and that was easily the biggest meal of the bunch.  We also had one pasta with their bolognese sauce which was also very very good.   All in all an excellent meal.

The waiter was very attentive to the fact two of our party had dairy allergies and checking on each item before serving.  Even not serving the peanut sauce with the chicken skewers because it contains cream.

Right off the bat we informed the waiter that we would all be paying separately and he told us no problem and at the end of the meal, he handled everything perfectly. So if you are a group all paying separately, just let them know when you sit down.  

Good beer and wine selection as well in a very relaxed atmosphere.  We were seated out on the "patio" where you're out in the open St Marks square area of the Venetian.  Live music was playing off in the distance which was fun.

Try the chicken Spring roles. Yum!!!
I absolutely love the pizza here. They are Wolfgang Puck's signature style; thin and very tasty. 
The restaurant is located in Caesers palace shopps and has a nice patio seating. You get to people watch and also enjoy a great meal. My favorite thing about it is that the prices is very reasonable for a Vegas restaurant and the quality of the food is perfecto!
I have never gone at a time that is very busy (or maybe it just never gets busy) but it won't hurt to make reservations just in case

Reasonable price, great food.

I had the Tomato & Basil Spaghettini and my husband had the Spinach Lasanga.  Both were fabulous as was the wine and bread.  I am huge fan of Wolfgang Puck and this is another great  one.  It has a great open feel, to make for a more casual lunch or dinner.

The food and wine was very tasty and they have a nice selection. Great or casual dining, happy hour at the bar and a great place to people watch.  Lots of singing and entertainment around the square to make it interesting. The staff was attentive but not very friendly. (Mine anyway) It's a very touristy spot so I'm sure they just try to get you in and out as fast as they can.  Fun, good place for eats.

My friend and I came here for a little snack to tide us over until a late-night dinner reservation. We were pleasantly surprised at how reasonably-priced the bar menu was and had the meatballs and the fries with garlic aioli along with two glasses of wine each -- we got out for under $50 which was perfect for a happy hour. The food wasn't anything to write home about but it was delicious nonetheless and the service was attentive but not overbearing. Great people watching spot and perfect little bar menu for some snacks. I'll remember this spot for next time!

We had a fantastic meal here one night and enjoyed some of the best people watching ever.  We started with the cheese plate and the caprese salad.  Everything was delicious, but there needed to be a better conduit for the cheese - more bread or crackers or something.  The waitstaff were teriffic, very attentive but not annoying.
There was a special richotta gnocci that night with chantarelle mushrooms and truffles - it was fantastic though the shaved truffles were ENORMOUS so a bit overwhelming.  Dave had the salmon and said it was the best thing he's ever eaten.  EVER. It did look amazing - perfectly cooked, crisp on the outside and served with these succulent julienned summer veggies.  Yum.  

The only confusion came from their website which made it seem as though there are two restaurants - a cafe and then a more upscale restaurant with a totally different menu.  They've now gotten rid of the restaurant menu and just use the cafe menu whether you eat inside or "outside".  I highly recommend Postrio for a fantastic meal and sit outside for the laugh riot that is the people watching in Las Vegas!

As part of our room package at the Venetian, we got a coupon for 25% off a meal at Postrio, so we decided to have a late dinner here one night.

We ended up having a seafood dinner, starting with the chilled shellfish platter. This consisted of two of the largest shrimp I've ever seen, two little oysters, and two endive leaves stuffed with a sort of seafood salad, served atop crushed ice and accompanied by a variety of sauces. It was all good, but seemed a bit overpriced at $39. My wife had a fish entree (I forget which one) and she enjoyed it. I had scallops, which tasty but a bit over-the-top with a heavy sauce and lardons.

The outdoor seating in "St. Marks Square" looked horrible, but the atmosphere inside the restaurant was actually very nice, with widely spaced tables. However, service was uneven--it started off pretty good, but then it seemed like our waiter disappeared during most of the meal.

Overall, this was not a particularly memorable meal, and had we not had the coupon, I probably would've felt ripped off.

Cookies are the only thing worth mentioning. I forgot what main course I had because they weren't memorable. Service could have been better but we opted to sit outside overlooking the venetian plaza. Im sure wolfgang has better places in vegas. Definitely not worth the price.

Amazing birthday dinner for my best friend. Our server Ricardo was the perfect complement - professional, appropriately attentive and personable. Wine, atmosphere, food = amazing. Five stars. Will absolutely return!

Good food. I ordered a pizza and tried some other things off the menu that the rest of my party ordered. Since we stayed at the Venetian, they gave us a ~20% off coupon so the bill came out to be really inexpensive. The service was really attentive and our food came out quickly for a party of 15.

While strolling at the Venetian, i happen to see this lovely bistro. It says Postrio by Wolfgang Puck. That name is always associated with good food so i decided to eat there. The hostess greeted me and promptly offered me a seat. The server quickly arrived to take my drink order while handing me the menu. I wasn't very hungry so i opted for the thin crust pizza with italian sausage and mushrooms. I asked my server if i could have burrata cheese which is my favorite and he said he will inform the chef. I like it when i can kinda personalize my meal according to my liking. Food came in about 15 minutes, i didn't even see it coming because i was enjoying the cloud like view of the hotel. Also, from my seat, i can see the performers doing their act. It was such a pleasant day to enjoy a good meal. The food is sumptuos and full of flavor. Every bite is just so heavenly. I never get to finish my meal, but if i didn't grab a light breakfast earlier, i definitely would gulp everything even the crust which i don't usually eat. I'm definitely coming back!

Went to Postrio for lunch on 3/4/07. I was actually trying to find Bouchon but got lost and was too hungry to continue on. 

I had a pasta with Bolognese sauce. It was all right, but the flavor didn't blow me away. The pasta was cooked al dente and good, but without a good sauce, the dish didn't quite hit the spot. My friend had the skirt steak sandwich with balsamic glazed onions, watercress, and blue cheese aioli. He said it was the best skirt steak he's ever had. And though I'm not a meat eater, I also thought the skirt steak was exceptional - very tender. The fries that came with it were hot and lightly mixed with parsley and parmesan. 

We sat in the courtyard and service was friendly and courteous.

I had the Roasted Mushroom Agnolotti with Black Truffle Butter and it was amazing, I wished I had saved some bread to soak up the last splashes of sauce.  My portion size was small to just enough, I left happy because it was rich and so delicious. Other members of my party got a pizza a largish portion for one person. They enjoyed the pizza but was not as wowed as myself. What my group got was that the sauces are the specialty so if you think the sauce sounds good than get the dish because it will be better than you imagined.

Visited in early June.  In terms of Wolfgang Puck places, I've been to the Las Vegas location of Spago as well, and this is the better restaurant.  Sure, it doesn't have the kitsch "Showgirls" value that the Spago in the Forum Shops at Caesars does, but the service was warmer and the food simply better.  I had pasta, which was executed well and was good comfort food but certainly nothing "last meal"-worthy.  You won't be disappointed, but it's not fireworks.

We've been here many times; this time was different. We love the lobster club but unfortunately between the five of us we didn't care for the clubs or the sauces for the crispy calamari. The lobster was chewy, service sucked, and we were really disappointed after much anticipation.
Had lunch on a Sunday.  Not bad at all,  but don't expect anything spectacular.  Perfect Martini was great.  I up to 4 star for that,  otherwise average.

I ordered the mushroom ravioli which was undercooked and had a sour unpleasant after taste to it.   My friend had the clam linguini which only had 4 clams , all shells and barely any sauce.  My other friends linguini was drenched in sauce and looked to have two orders of clams in it.  My one star is based solely on the food as the service was decent. They should spend less time pushing drinks and concentrate more on the food quality.

Dined late on a Tuesday night.  Postrio was everything I would expect from a Puck restaurant.  The food was very good....not amazing.  The service was very friendly but extremely slow.  I would return to try more dishes as long as I could walk in without a reservation.

Overall we had a nice long dinner and we all enjoyed the food.

The food here is decent - no complaints there - but the service was so spotty that I can really only give two stars. Seriously, we waited a good 15 minutes before anyone even came over  to bring us water and menus and then at least another 15 or so for the water to come and drink orders to be taken. Our waiter was around during the beginning, though almost everything else was taken care of by other servers. I can handle a slow kitchen from time to time, but it's a lot easier of a pill to swallow if your server is on top of it with drinks and bread to tide you over. 

There were 7 of us dining at Postrio last week - we started with some apps including the calamari/shrimp, house-made sausage trio and a roasted quail dish that isn't on the online menu. I only sampled the calamari and it was indeed tasty - I especially liked the sauce that came with it. Everyone seemed to like the other selections so that was a bonus.

For an entrée I was torn between the rib eye and something more Italian. I don't normally love gnocchi, but the description of the Ricotta Gnocchi sounded so great, I wanted to try it. It was very, very good. The ricotta in the gnocchi gave it a great flavor and texture that I usually don't associate with gnocchi - it was lighter, less dense. Overall really tasty.

Again, decent food but definitely sub-par service. With so many great restaurants in Vegas to choose from, I'll definitely give something else a try next time if we're dining at the Venetian.

First impression, BIG black mark against! One of my pet peeves is restaurants that only serve flavoured iced teas. Especially the tropical crap which has become so popular in recent years. I like tea-flavoured tea, damnit! The tropical crap has gotten so common that I habitually ask if they have normal iced tea when ordering. I did so at Postrio and, when given proper assurance, ordered. Trusting what I was told, I added my preferred sweetener and took a drink. And it was all I could do not to spit that tropical crap all over St. Mark's Square!!! 

Ok. They've mostly redeemed themselves. The heirloom tomato caprese is delicious, and the prosciutto panini is just decadent! 

Five stars for the food. Five for the service *after* the drink ordering. Marked down to three overall because that always pisses me off!

AMAZING! Applies to both food and service. I had the spicy pizza cant remember the exact name but the best pizza I have ever had. My wife had the linguine and loved it. This place is a must when visiting vegas.

I had the prosciutto pizza which was pretty good.  It was listed as a pesto based pizza, instead of marinara, but I like the 4-cheese pesto one way better.  The location was nice and we were able to watch a live show going on next door in the Venetian.

Last night we went over to the Venetian and chose Postrio for the variety of food. I had a gluten free pasta they made me with a sausage bolgnase sauce. Delish!  At our table we also had two different pizzas and a spaghetti with meatballs.  Everyone loved their dinner and left nothing to take home. The waiters were good and decently attentive. We had wine refills and water, they took away dirty plates without being disruptive, and a nice 'fake' outdoorsy feel to the 'patio'.  They didn't have a specific gluten free menu but were very informed on what I could eat. It's so nice not have salad all the time when out with friends.

Came here on NYE (2nd time on NYE).  Excellent, excellent service.  Attentive, good memories, great teamwork.  5 stars.

The food, however, was just meh.  2 stars.  

Caesar salad = excellent.  Anchovies were fresh, but pickled -- I prefer mine salted in oil.  

I had potato soup with a black truffle gremolata and while there were definitely some kind of mushroom shavings in the soup, they didn't taste truffley - so hard to justify the $24 price tag without the truffle experience.  

I also had the quail starter which turned out to be quail legs l'orange (why didn't they just call it that on the menu?) and super rich.  The first time it came out, it was raw.  I've seen "medium" quail before, but it was cold inside too = not safe to eat.  They were cool when I asked them to redo the dish and brought it back in a jiffy cooked through.  

They brought us a complimentary dessert to make up for the quail fiasco (cookies and creme brulee), which was also very nice.  

Overall, service was outstanding, but the food...   Wolfgang, what happened?!

Barely seems worth writing a review of since I went in for a quick lunch.  That being said, the food was quite good.  I ordered a pizza with fennel sausage, cippolini onions, wild mushrooms, and goat cheese with a side of fries.  The pizza was good, but nothing worth writing home over, especially since the crust was a bit soggy and the sauce wasn't as flavorful as I had hoped.  The fries, on the other hand, were exceptional.  They were crispy, salty, and hot (it also didn't hurt that they were served a garlic-herb aioli that I would dip just about anything in!).  The drink I ordered (hey don't judge, just because it's lunch doesn't mean I can't have a drink! plus it's Vegas!) was average and I could have likely had a better one for about 5 bucks at the bar down the street from me in New Orleans.  Good food, not great, but I won't judge chef Puck on this effort.

Love LOve LOVe LOVE this place! Everything I had was amazing!! 

We started off with an array of different appetizers - the list consisted of various different pizzas, grown up pigs in a blanket, mini crab cakes, fried calamari, and this little fried mushroom and rice balls (I don't know the proper names). My favorite would be the fried calamari - it's salt and pepper calamari with rock shrimp and then topped with a sweet Thai chili sauce. It has that spicy kick to it! My second favorite was the dish I didn't know the name of (little fired mushroom and rice balls). They were so packed with flavor, that every bit I took I felt like my mouth was about to explode.

When it came to dinner, even though I was super full, I had the lobster roll sandwich which came with a side of fries. The lobster roll sandwich was good and  huge. If I could only make a slight change, it would to have them put a little less of the mayo on the dish. Other than that it was really really good. So good that even though I was stuffed after the first bit, I pushed myself to eat one half of the sandwhich and then eat the other halfs lobter only. As far as the fries are concerned, they were made just how I like them. Super thin, crispy, and covered in salt and pepper. They reminded me of a better version of McDonald's. (I know I know I shouldn't compare these two places, but I do love there fries...Sorry).

As far as dessert, we had another array of desserts. Now even though I was super stuffed, I had a little bit of room for a taste test. We had apple strudel. mini chocolate donuts filled with camel, strawberry souffle, and a smore cake. My favorite was the smore came. Graham cracker bottom, dark chocolate fudge middle, and then topped off with a torched marshmallow. Yum YUm YUM!!!

We had lunch here with a party of 6 total. We were staying in the hotel and didn't want to venture far for our first meal of the day. We waited about 15 minutes to get a table which is about average for a party of this size. Once seated we did have to wait another while before having water served. It seemed as though they were short staffed or just weren't prepared to have this many people at the restaurant on a Monday (12/31/12). We expected to have someone filling our glasses before going empty, but that is not what occurred. Our waters were filled, drink and food orders were taken, then we waited for what seemed like a longer while before our food was served. There were a few salads and soups ordered which were served prior to the main courses. The Butternut Squash soup was amazing! Salads were fresh and the anchovies were also fresh. The other dishes came out and looked appetizing. Pizza's were ordered and shared among the table. The Fennel Sausage pizza was a bit on the bland side and not what was expected as far as taste goes. It pretty much was a Pepperoni Pizza with a fancy name. The Mushroom Pizza on the other hand was delicious. The Goat cheese really added flavor to it and complimented the mushrooms. I'd give this restaurant another try if I were in the hotel again. Overall great food, not so great service for a restaurant of this category.

So after a day and a half, the staff working with us on this returned our phone calls to tell us that the waiter who committed this crime has been terminated from his job, all of the money we spent on our meal will be refunded and they were extremely sorry.  I appreciate that they took the time to see that this was an issue and handled it.

I may return again.

A dinner date here is always sets the right mood for the evening with its superb service, mouth-watering food, and romantic ambiance.  The salmon is baked in a paper wrap and when they slice it open...oooo la la!  My boyfriend swears by the risotto there though.  He's completely enamored with it!

Unbelievably awesome dining experience...looking for breakfast on a Saturday at noon...almost waited in line at one of the "Denny-ish" type hotel restaurants...walked to the shopping area of Venetian and found this Wolfgang Puck establishment...realized they had Brunch...and it is GREAT....great menu, great food, and the best service from the multitude of highly competent servers...including Trevor and Omar ask for them
Wasn't expecting much but really enjoyed my lightly breaded and perfectly fried shrimp and calamari. The short ribs were good, too. Terrific service. An oasis in a sea of tacky.

I don't remember that many things about Postrio, but it had a couple of stand out extremely good dishes:

- the best meatloaf of my life
- great pizza
- amazing ginger-fruit cocktail
- chocolate beignets

Also solid fish dishes! Basically I am a Wolfgang fan.  Good bread, always solid food, nice drinks.  The only thing about Postrio I don't particularly enjoy is the campyness of its setting (if you sit outside), but some people like that, I guess.  It's part of the allure.  I'm mostly basing this 4 star review on the most recent trip I've made there, but I will admit that it's not always good.  The first time I went there, it was very underwhelming, and I distinctly remember a disappointing duck, but it's very solid on the whole.

love it love it love it!

I got to try 6 different dishes for only $55! 

I went to dinner at Postrio all by myself and asked if they had a tasting menu (even though they didn't have a sign for one). The chef said I could choose 4 different dishes from their menu or I could leave the choosing up to the chef.

I decided to leave it up to the chef and he chose to give me 6 different dishes- tempura (squash, zucchini) with basil aoli sauce, english pea soup, wild corn ravioli,  prosciutto with melon, mushroom gnocchi, and beef tenderloin! I ate everything presented to me because it was all delicious and so generous considering that I'm not really ordering off the menu (some dishes were chef's creations not on the menu) and I was only being charged $55. 

Even the pea soup, which I was not looking forward to because I hate peas, was delicious! It was presented in a little tea cup so it was just enough for me to taste and enjoy without overwhelming myself.  
 
I sat at the bar which allowed me to be out in the open part of the restaurant and interact with the bartender as well as other patrons.  Great food, great conversation, great atmosphere. All in all, I will be going back and I'm going to try the Postrio in SF. Hopefully it will live up to the experience given by its Vegas counterpart.

Wa
y overpriced for what you get. The menu is so mediocre as is the service and the portions are ridiculous! I know this is prime real estate but the empty restaurant should have been a warning sign. $30 will get you a teeny piece of FARMED raised salmon. The waiter was arrogant and we will not be in a hurry to return to this place!

Food was solid and ambiance was nice. We sat "outside" for lunch and my mom ordered from the brunch menu, while I ordered the lobster club and a glass of champagne. It's a fun place to eat while you're shopping in the Venetian; service was good too.

I love the Venetian!  The painted walls and ceilings, the street performers...a little piece of Venice.  So naturally having lunch in this open space restaurant sounded like a terrific idea.  
The 20 minute wait was no problem, there are multiple restaurants around so we had a glass of wine at a neighboring bar.  Once seated we ordered our drinks, since I'm from Miami, whenever I order a caipirinha i take into consideration that not everybody understand what its suppose to taste like.  Unfortunately it was so awful that both me and my friend had to send our drinks back.  Then when our waiter kindly recommended the pomegranate mojitos, i nervously accepted.  Also terrible but I was not about to return two cocktails.  

So now for the food; boring.  Maybe I'm being bias because of my superb experience with the Wolfgang Puck Bar and Grill @ the MGM but the food was nothing special.  I was expecting a savory pasta dish and what i served was can only be described as ordinary.  

Very disappointing, you have all the right components, step up your game Postrio!!
I ordered the crispy salmon dish on a blended pea sauce.  The blended pea sauce was actually refreshing.  The salmon on the other hand was nothing to rave about.

Two stars because though the food wasn't terrible, neither was it amazing. And with the price and the name brand, well, it ought to be a cut above. It wasn't. 

Calamari was done well with a sweet dipping sauce. However, the hard-as-a-rock butter that accompanied the bread was unusable, and the ravioli was below average. Undercooked, under filled, and with a too-salty sauce. I've had significantly better and cheaper experiences and ravioli at the Bravo Italian chain. 

To sum it up: underwhelming.

My girlfriend and I had dinner here the last time thru the Venetian. The menu had so many good things it took me forever to figure out what I wanted but i defiantly made the right choice. I had the braised rib ravioli. The meat inside was so tender and juicy, the ravioli was made with fresh pasta and the sauce was unreal. I could have put it in a cup and drank it with a straw it was so good. Unfortunately my girlfriend did not get the right thing. She was in the mood for linguine and clams and when it came out she tried one bite and said she did not like it. I reached over to give it a try and all I could smell was olive oil. It had no flavor except olive oil and we sent it back. I still give this place 4 stars cause the service and the ravioli and bread and salad was all great, oh and the wine. So many great places to eat in Vegas, I'm glade I made it here.

So I didn't really eat a full meal here.  I only had dessert and coffee at the bar, so my review may not really be a fair 5 stars.

With that said, their CHOCOLATE BEIGNETS were to die for!  Combined with a small dollop of ice cream they served with it, it was a perfect dessert.  Paired with a simple cup of coffee, I was fully satisfied.

Food portions were pretty good and the prices were moderate.  The ambiance is great because you have the outdoor seating with the various performances going on.  The service wasn't great and it can get loud at times, so I wouldn't recommend having a formal dinner here.  The attire here is very diverse.  Some people are dressed up while others are wearing shorts and sandals.  Don't know how to describe this place but a fancy sports bar with good food.  

I got the shrimp pesto pizza which sounded odd but it ended up being pretty good.  I must warn you though that if you are lactose or don't like goat cheese this isn't for you.  My g/f got the meatloaf which was interesting take.  The sauce for the meatloaf and mashed potatoes was rich and herby, but the soggy onions kinda threw me off.  Overall I would go here again, for its a great place to start your vegas trip

The wine fanatics seemed to have a VERY good time, and the rest of us had a darned good meal.  Our group of seven included on friend who keeps Robert Parker's newest wine reviews on his iPhone, so three different red wines were ordered, minutely studied, and consumed.  The wine list was thorough, and the staff was knowledgeable about what they had available.  Those of us interested in the food where very impressed by the pumpkin soup and the fried calamari (very light with no oily taste).  Two tried the Alaskan halibut and liked both the fish and the interesting corn, mushroom and tomato side dishes.  Great bread, BTW -- I think we consumed 3 loaves.

Awful experience at  normally reliable restaurant.  Service was slow and inattentive.  Food was overcooked, undercooked, or came out cold or soggy.  Scallops were particularly bad-- texture was mushy like pre-frozen Costco fare.  I will never do dinner there again.  (Though I will be back for the lobster club at lunch. . .)

While undoubtably the food here is fine, diner's must keep their eyes on their wallets at all times, lest they be picked by the Puck.  My wife and I and three other couples strolled the Grand Canal and chose Postrio for dinner this particular evening. We're all foodies and while on business we indulge when we can.  After ordering drinks, the waitress (or accomplice) told us about the specials.  One appetizer caught my ear - shrimp, oysters,  clams and half a boiled lobster on ice.  I said "Let's have one of those, then we'll order." She asked "Would you like it for the table?" "Yes," I replied, "We'll share it." So she brought two to the table. I only ordered one but it's just an appetizer, why not? So here we see two bowls of ice with a few small shrimp, a few oysters and half a baby lobster - $135 each.  Nice!  So make sure you ask the price before ordering any special or you're likely to get Wolfgang Pucked up the bum.

The wine selection and the food here is pretty decent. The seafood cioppino here is pretty solid. It's not overly season or watery. The saffron definitely comes through. When I was here my group ordered the tuna tartare and calamari appetizer. The tuna tartare didn't really knock my socks off but the calamari was nice and light.

Went for dinner on friday to celebrate my cousin's birthday. Since we like Italian and the place seemed to have options for all of us(limited as it was) we decided to try it. The food was amazing and our server was impressive(she made everything sound delish, esp the desert and it was)..
I tried fettucine with wild mushrooms and loved it. 
The rest loved the chicken picata(which 2 of them chose) and the spagetthi with scallops....
The desert was fab...creme brulee was good.
we also ordered a rasberry souffle which came in a fluffy choc cake with amazing choclate sauce...I had to tell myself to stop eating it! One of the best deserts I had...
I told the server it was my cousin's birthday  and it would be great if she could get a candle with her desert....they arranged her desert on a plate with happy birthday written in choclate sauce and a candle..it was done beautifully and my cousin was happy and surprised!!
There was a violinist performing in the area next to the restaurant and that made the evening even more enjoyable. I will be going back soon!!

Went for a birthday dinner on Saturday night.  The service couldn't have been nicer.  My friend was treated like a queen!

Oysters, margherita pizza, and I forget what else we started with.  Five had the lasagna, and every single one of them cleaned their plate.  In fact no matter what anyone had, their plate was demolished.  The food was that good.

Then, the desserts came, and there was such an array.  Pumpkin whoopie pies, all sorts of different cookes, mousses, ice cream, creme brulee, etc., etc., etc.  They just kept coming.

Postrio was delicious and worth digging through the horrid St. Mark's Square nonsense in the Venetian.

Ate here on a friend's recommendation, so good. The Braised Oxtail and some kind of ricotta pasta I had was amazing. My friend had a a Rabbit and noodle dish that was really tasty too. The server was really nice. We ordered a Garlic Soup with Lobster and he had the kitchen split it for us. The server, I forgot his name, didn't treat us like tourist and once he found out we were locals he bought us dessert. I plan to go back with my husband for a special occasion.

This is another Wolfgang Puck restaurant that I was disappointed by. It goes to show that too many of his restaurants rely on his name to get business, instead of focusing on quality of food, experience, or innovation. Nothing was incredibly really bad about this, but the entire experience was incredibly forgettable and pedestrian. Price/quality ratio of food was just not good, and the food somehow reminded me of chain restaurant fare. The dining experience itself was also below average - the tables were cramped way too closely together, and I felt like I was squished in a corner and practically sitting on the diners at the next table. (I can only imagine how a truly claustrophobic person would feel.) With so many amazing restaurants in Vegas, I wouldn't recommend wasting a meal on Postrio, unless you've already eaten your way through the hundreds of other renowned establishments in the area.

I have no complaints for this place. My boyfriend took me out to dinner here and I was pleasantly surprised by the friendliness of our waitress and the bus guy. We had clams, mussels, and a shrimp louis salad, and two apple strudels for dessert, what a treat. this is a great restaurant and i'm sure it wouldn't disappoint.

So, there are certainly some things I do not like to eat and will not eat (poorly cooked okra, hachiya persimmons, raw oysters, and other assorted matter of objects which texture resembles mucus), but in no way do I consider myself to be a Picky Eater.  I don't think there is a strict definition of a Picky Eater, but as all of you know, you know it when you see it.  A Picky Eater is not the same as someone who is Gastronomically Educated and is therefore selective, I must make that quick distinction.  Anyway. 

I ended up at Postrio because I was traveling with some Picky Eaters, the kind who like hamburgers and fries, and eschew all manner of vegetal stuffs.  They wanted to go to Outback Steakhouse, which distressed me, but people like Whiny Food Snobs just about as much as they like Picky Eaters.  

Postrio is affordable Las Vegas fare, the service is quick, and with the kind of menu they are sporting, it's fairly unlikely that you're going to get food poisoning.  I mean, they have PIZZA, and as a bailout meal, a margherita pizza is very very hard to wreck.  Also you can watch people look up at the painted sky ceiling in the Venetian and watch them stumble into each other, that is fun.

After much hype about the lobster club, we went for lunch last weekend.  I think it's overpriced and under delivered.  The lobster club and soft shell crab sandwich were $29 each.  Really?  A $29 sandwich?  I've never never heard of such a thing.  But my buddy had been raving about it and so I had to try it.  While it had a lot of lobster, it was completely bland.  The toasted bread was too hard for such delicate meat.  The crab po boy was also bland and forgettable.  I tried my friend's french onion soup and mushroom ravioli.  The soup was too sweet and the ravioli was under cooked. I love al dente but this was sticking to my teeth.  The best things we had were the lasagna, fries, and coffee.  The place has a nice set up but the food was amiss.

THE BEST BURGER EVER!!!! for someone who never craves burgers on the way to vegas all i can think about is the burger here. the onion marmalade with the sharp vermont cheddar and the juicy prime beef burger. AMAZINGNESS!
Beyond amazing service and friendly servers, great pasta and wine!  Best value in the Venetian!

Good food, great service, romantic setting...but as with every pricey restaurant, be prepared to leave hungry.  I  Ordered the seabass with a side of asparagus, a bottle of wine, dessert, and my wife got the wild mushroom Gnoochi.  Maybe we shouldve ordered more appetizers and sides, but our bill was already $130 not including tip.  So I do what I usually do at fancy places and just kept asking for more bread, which was good and filled me up.  Seabass was really good but not filling.  Mushroom Gnoochi was good, but the portion was so small my wife was starving after dinner.  After tip we spend around $150, and still had to find another place to eat afterwards just to keep our stomachs from growling.

This was my first time at a wolfgang puck restaurant...What better place than the venetian with live opera for entertainment.  Plus the look and feel of an outdoor piazza doesn't hurt.

We were here for our last brunch and had delicious food along w. great service.

charcuterie plate: no joke, very good but wow...a LOT of meat
spicy tuna tartare: delicious, the tuna and avocado went well together for a rich creamy taste on top of the crisp wonton
ricotta gnocchi with wild mushrooms and black summer truffles: YUM YUM YUMMM!!  This was a fave at our table, really rich and sooo good
house made lasagna: large portion and also delicious! you can't go wrong with lasagna, nice and hearty...somewhat heavy for brunch but my friend needed to coat her stomach after a late night out!

We had a great brunch.  This was a great first experience with wolfgang puck.

Postrio is a reasonably priced, semi-fancy place for dinner in Vegas. Being not too familiar with the Venetian, we had a hard time finding it. When we did find it, apparently our names weren't under the reservations when I clearly placed one the day before - luckily it wasn't crazy busy so we were seated "outdoors" right away anyway. I had the organic roasted chicken which was heavenly and boyfriend had the penne bolognese which was super yummy as well. There was quite a wait for the food, but the service was good and who's in a rush when you're at a nice place like Postrio.

Came here to meet some colleagues while at a convention for work around 7pm and we were seated at the lounge area inside. It's actually really cute I mean you can pretty much eat on the patio "outside" under the "sky" in St. Marks Square! Super cute ambiance.

My review is only based on drinks and a couple appetizers. I would recommend getting their Moscow mule if you like them. It was the first drink on their menu and I usually get them but this was probably one of the best moscows I've had. The Ginger Beer was really good! I mean it had a great kick to it and I'm a little sad I didn't check to see what kind they used because it was really good! We also go the shrimp tempura and tuna tartare and I'm not sure if it's because I was starving but I thought they were good lol. I guess I should say my review is mostly about the drink I had lol- I still compare the ginger beer I had in that drink to any I have now. 

I'd probably come back to try their food but I really liked the ambiance and the the Mule so all in all I had a great time here for drinks and appetizers before going out for more drinks after.

One of my favorite places to eat dinner in Vegas.   It's nice without being stuffy, intricately cooked without being pompous and romantic without being kitschy.   You can eat on the patio and enjoy St. Mark's square, or the more formal dining room.

Everything I've eaten here has been great, and very reasonably priced for the quality.   I've had the fliet, the duck and the tilapia (i think... it was like a year and a half ago. i know it was an obscene chunk of delicious fish).  However, the real stars of Postrio, as with any Puck restaurants, are the desserts.  I've twice enjoyed the pistachio gelato with port cherries.  So good.  So very good.

The formal dining room is great for a nice, romantic dinner.  The patio is great for something more laid back.

This restaurant is located in the Venetian. The food was delicious, although customer service is extremely slow. I ordered the Pea Soup for an appetizer, which was very tasteful. Thick & creamy, topped off with dungenous crab. The white corn ravioli entree was good too, but could've used a little more flavor- more cheese perhaps? 

Heard there's one in SF as well. I would definitely go back...

Umm, it's a mixed review for me. First of all, the good parts.

I absolutely love Postrio's (and the Venetian in general) definition of 'patio dining.' Our large group of 10 was really hesitant to grab the patio because we were in town during the fall when it's quite cold outside. Well, we had the faux outdoor dining inside the Venetian so the temperature was very comfy. 

The service was okay, our server was slightly too slow in paying us attention and in our orders. They did help us celebrate my friend's birthday with a complementary dessert for her. 

Food was the tossup, really. The piece of calamari that I had was delicious, light and crisp. My friend Teri offered me some of her bouillabaisse and it was the best seafood stew I've had. Well, the downside was the reason why Teri offered me some of her food in the first place. My pumpkin tortellini, for $21, only had six measly pieces. The pasta itself was beyond al dente and was partially raw in the middle. There was not enough pumpkin stuffing inside. My friend Aries, who also ordered the same, and I looked at each other and thought that they might have split our order. There was nowhere near enough. That was the disappointing aspect of the dinner.

Ambiance was great, the company was awesome, some deduction for the value, food, and service.

This really is a fun place to eat. You get the feeling of being outside on a patio but without the wind and the cold. Service was fantastic, ambiance was great, and my boyfriend and I both enjoyed the food. I had the mushroom pizza and he had one of the pasta dishes, but it all looked pretty good. :)
Excellent service and fantastic good. Try the Crisp Pork Schnitzel...incredible!!!  Lots of options in the Venetian/Palazzo, don't underestimate Postrio.  It's good stuff!

If you do nothing else make sure you order the calamari and rock shrimp appetizer.  Hands down the best calamari I've ever had.  The prices overall are not bad for Vegas, especially considering this is in one of the nicer hotels.  The service was great and the food was great.  It's one of the better places I've eaten at in Vegas and I've been to many.

I give this place 3.5 stars! .,.. the name was so confusing bc it had wolfgang puck in it buuuuut yelp notified me a couple days later i got it wrong ):

My friend and i were starving and trying to soak up fat tuesday alcohol with some food and we decided on this place ! We originally wanted to go to the restaurant next door/across the walkway, but the waitresses/hostesses were super snobby and rude there, so we came here instead, where the employees were incredibly nice to us. 

We had seen their happy hour everyday all day and was very curious in their small medium and large plates. Their prices even NOT on happy hour were very reasonable, especially for overpriced Vegas food and meals. We were seated at the bar for happy hour specials and were handed some complimentary popcorn from the bartender working there. After contemplating on the menu, we decided on:

-wild mushroom pizza ($16): loaded with lots of mushrooms, but it was alright. for a restaurant that also had a pizzeria, i thought it would be fantastic! but the crust was kind of hard and the overall pizza was kinda cold.... 
-homemade meatballs ($6): comes in 3 meatballs the size of half a fist, maybe smaller and a slice of bread. The meat was soft when you bit into it. You cant really taste too much of the beef(?) but the sauce was delicious
-garlic aoli french fries ($7): MMM this was the highlight of our meal. If you like soft or like yard house fries, you will definitely like this! They give you mustard and ketchup but you can really just eat it with no condiments. 

I would have given them a 3 stars, but the service was superb! The bartender checked up on us frequently and entertained us with questions and experiences about his trip to Europe. And when we packed the stuff to go, he gave us a cute little box for the pizza and an extra container of ketchup. 

Overall, i think this is a cute restaurant to go to for cheap food in Vegas! For under $30, you can feed two people for dinner! But then again, we had fat tuesday alcohol in our stomach and we're petite LOL

Well Wolfgang, you did well my friend.

This place was great to grab my last meal in Vegas on my business trip.  I enjoyed a salad with added chicken while enjoying a show right outside the dining area.  

The restaurant is a lot bigger than it looks and would be great to impress a large group.

Nice spot for lunch!  My husband and I shared the prosciutto panini and some braised short rib ravioli dish.  All in all quite satisfying, nothing negative and nothing that I was really over the moon about.  The ambiance is nice though.  I like the feeling of dining outdoors while indoors.  In fact, there was even a rogue pigeon that flew across our table at the end of our meal.  I wonder how it got in??

Three words....SUMMER....TRUFFLE....RISOTTO!!!!
I was lucky enough dine at Postrio as a guest of the GM...so our party of 8 tried EVERYTHING on the menu. The food is wonderful, expensive...but very good...no disappointment here. Now, I probably would have given this restaurant 4 stars, but the SUMMER TRUFFLE RISOTTO bumped them up to 10 stars! I can still taste this risotto in my mouth, I dream about it, I crave it...and I may have called this past weekend to see if they had it as a special again.....sadly, they didn't..... :( I will call every time I go to Vegas, hoping that I will again taste that heavenly SUMMER TRUFFLE RISOTTO.

On our trip to Vegas we decided to try Postrio.  We had a 7:30 reservation and our table was ready but set almost in the walking path of the mall.  Our waiter was nice and said we had to try the specials Duck and Double Pork Chop.  So 2 of us ordered the Duck and 2 of us ordered the Double Pork Chop.  We ordered some salads to start.  20 minutes later the waiter came back to inform us they had ran out of the Duck and only had one pork left.  He brought menus back so we could reorder.  Then we waited and waited and waited.  At 8:40 we finally received our salads.  By 9:40 we has received our main course.  Our daughter by this time was almost asleep at the table.  The food when it finally came was ok.  Nothing really special and it was expensive.  I did expect a lot more from a Wolfgang Puck restaurant.  We will be returning to Vegas but not Postrio.

Puck again hits a home run!  We have gone to several of his restaurants and have not been disappointed yet. 

We had brunch-the omelet was delicious as were the pancakes. Trevor was attentive and took great care of us. Omar kept the coffee flowing and this is important in Vegas in the morning!  Great views as it is close to the gondolas with faux sky and buildings. Very relaxing setting. We will be back!

This restaurant is tucked in St. Mark's Square at The Venetian, where (if you sit "outside") you can enjoy a mini opera performance or see people crowded around the moving statues. Hailing from the SF Bay Area, I'm sad to say that I've never gone to the Postrio in San Francisco, but I'm glad that I got to try it in Vegas.

They serve you a nice crusty bread with pesto and an olive tapenade.

When I first came here (over 2 years ago), I had a spaghettini with mushrooms and truffle oil. It was so good! Unfortunately, it has been taken off the menu. The second time around, I came here with my cousin. We both started with the asparagus soup, which was creamy and slightly filling, a great opener for our lunch. I ordered the Atlantic King Salmon (sashimi grade!) -- seared to perfection, and slightly raw on the inside -- served with artichokes, tomatoes and other spring vegetables. My cousin had the prime burger. It was pretty standard, but the red onion marmalade was unforgettable!

A little pricey but not expensive. This is my go to place if I'm at the Venetian. I suggest you go!
Sausage pizza is good. Chose it based on a suggestion.  Took a bit to get the initial service, but it went quick and well after.

Being in the heart of the Venetian, I was sure this place would be incredibly expensive. However, the dishes came out to be about 20 dollars a plate, affordable for the place and ambiance this place offered. 

I ordered the bolognese here. Delicious! The pasta's texture was just perfect. It felt like it had substance. The spices in the sauce were subtle but tasty.
