The spectacular Venetian "St Marks Square" location, offers al fresco dining without the elements but does offer great people watching, classical music performances across the square and a general nice buzz of people having a good time. friendly staff are pleasant, welcoming and professional.

I opted for three appetizers, a spinach salad with apple shavings, pomegranates, candied walnuts, fennel and blue cheese, which was perfectly balanced so all the unique flavors and textures both stood out and complimented each other.  The miniature salmon sliders were very well flavored. The chicken satay was juicy with a spicy peanut sauce that that really delivered a delicious flavor and burn.

Add it all up and once again Wolfgang and Postrio delivered the goods!

If you're looking for a quiet place to have dinner and to hold a conversation with your dinner partner, do not go here.

Like any restaurant in Vegas, probably best to make reservations to avoid a wait. However, there is first come first serve seating at the bar with full menu for those of you that have to eat and run.

Ordered the chilled shrimp cocktail to start. The shrimp is still it's in its shell and won't be served in a glass. The shrimp were actually quite delicious and very meaty. The cocktail sauce was decent. Was it the best shrimp cocktail I've ever had? No. Was it better than the average shrimp cocktail. Yes. If you do decide to go to Postrio despite my review you can be assured the shrimp cocktail is not the reason why I gave Postrio two stars.

My main entree was the capellini pasta with grilled shrimp, calamari and spicy tomato sauce. You may notice that the menu actually includes mussels as well, but there were no mussels present in my serving. Also the capellini seemed overcooked and mushy. This was a huge disappointment. I can expect sub par pasta from a restaurant that doesn't specialize in Italian cuisine, but considering this is an Italian restaurant and a Wolfgang Puck restaurant no less, I was extremely disappointed.

Undoubtedly you can find a better Italian restaurant on the strip otherwise you're up for a huge disappointment at Postrio.

In short: Delicious seafood (oysters and mussels) with fantastic pasta.

As I have been brainwashed by the cheese platter at Batali's San Marco right across the way at the Venetian, I had never noticed this place except that Wolfgang Puck has some restaurant in the corner.  Club Grazie sent me a complimentary dinner here so I checked it out with the GF this past Wednesday evening.

We were seated inside (would have been a 10 minute wait outside.  Inside is mood lit, clean, and less distracting which is great for a date and/or you're ugly (as in my case).  It felt more formal inside too, but the outside is nice if you want to see/hear the violinists or jesters, but you may also enjoy the crowd of tourists passing by.

Here's the menu: (http://www.venetian.com/uploadedFiles/The_Venetian/Dining/Fine_Dining/PostrioDinner0410.pdf)

Very friendly and accomodating waiter, simple wine menu (I like that). Also of note, the bread and butter comes with a crushed olive/basil/olive oil dipping sauce for the Italian bread that was really good.

We started off with a few of the kumamoto oysters which were phenomenal.  It's funny how you can get some of the freshest seafoods and meats in the middle of the desert.

We then split the caesar salad which had a nice deconstructed take on an old favorite.  It has a very flavorful white anchovie slice served with whole lettuce leaves which are tossed with the caesar dressing which IMO had the perfect balance of acidity and creaminess.  Great salad and it might be the first one where I've needed a knife to eat.

For entrees, I ordered the steamed black mussels in a white wine sauce and the GF got the spinach lasagna with meat sauce.  My one let down was the bearnaise sauce that covered the bread with my mussels.  It was too sweet, sour, and creamy for my taste, the GF didn't like it either.  The mussels tasted great, but I was not blown away, it was about what I expected when ordering steamed mussels.

The GF's spinach ravioli on the other did blow me away.  I recommend this dish to anyone who likes pasta in meat sauces.  I'll upload some of the iphone pics in a bit, but the pasta was perfectly soft and the meat sauce had great flavors of the beef and sausage.

For dessert, save room for the beinet.  Fried chocolate doughnuts with chocolate and caramel inside that melts in your mouth, served with coffee ice cream and a vanilla sauce... We got them on the waiter's recommendation and they turned out to be one of the best desserts I've had in a long time.

Next time I'll try the linguine in white clam sauce and the four cheese ravioli since the pasta was so good.  The pizzas didn't look special from the other tables, so I'll stick with San Marco when I want a pizza.

We went to Postrio yesterday for a light lunch upon our arrival at The Venetian.  Cool setting but the hostess and wait staff were a little bit on the snooty side.  The waiter was visibly annoyed when my wife asked for bread with her salad.  We didn't load up with lots of wonderful different dishes, nor did we come at dinner time. My wife had the caesar salad with chicken, and I had the pizza with baby squash, roasted chicken and smoked mozzarella.  I regretted not getting the pizza with the fennel sausage but my pizza was fine, as was my wife's salad.  The chicken was good, but there really wasn't anything exceptional about our meal.  Maybe it was what we ordered.  I don't know.  But still, it was fine, if a bit pricey for what we got.

Just okay.  Started with a caesar salad which consisted of four lettuce wedges, drizzled with caesar dressing and topped with hunks of blue cheese and anchovy.  Not a huge fan of lettuce wedges because they are a pain to eat.  It always ends up going everywhere.  The dressing was good though.

I had the scallops which was a nightly special.  Seared scallops, roasted vegetables and a pea pistachio puree.  The scallops were cooked well but that puree was just odd.  Not a great flavor and this dish would have been a lot better without it.  At least the company I was with was good!

The food was really nothing special, but it is a cool little atmosphere.  Located in the Cannal Shoppes and if you sit on their version of a "patio," you can entertain yourself watching the little performances staged near the restaurant.  For those of you who choose your restaurants to accomodate rug rats, I think if you sit in this area, it would be good for kids.  We had a 3 month old with us and it provided easy access to the closest bathroom for diaper changes!

The staff had worked with my friends to get their money returned to them and we were told that thief of a waiter was terminated.

I would possibly come back here when in Vegas again, but otherwise I think I can find similar dishes at Wolfgang's other restaurants in LA.

This is a review for the cafe.

My first trip to Las Vegas (like my second) was very short and sweet. My last family vacation before marriage, it was great fun but Vegas in June proved to be a mistake. 

Because of the sizzling temperatures we didn't leave the Venetian Hotel for 48 hours. The extreme dryness and cigarette smoke caused a few bloody noses and some yucky allergies, but we did manage to have some good family time before gratefully returning home. 

In a city with glorious high end food I maintained discipline a month before my wedding, but I did manage to scarf down the best chicken salad sandwich I've ever had at Postrio, Wolfgang Puck's cafe in St. Mark's Square. 

The moist chicken salad was combined with celery, apples, and port glazed grapes on pecan-raisin toast. Mom and I shared this sandwich and I was so sorry when my half was gone.

My husband and I had lunch here a few Saturdays ago. Restaurant was serving both brunch and lunch. We decided to go with the lunch menu. Options included soups, salads, pizzas, pastas and sandwiches. We started with the gazpacho which was outstanding. Very refreshing, ricotta was an aMazing addition and it was the best thing we tried. My husband had the burger which was also excellent...very fresh, and it came with bacon aioli...who doesn't like that??

I had the Sweet Corn agnolloti. It was tasty, but lacked some seasoning. The fresh pasta was excellent and the corn and ricotta was a creative combination. I wouldn't get it again, would go for a different pasta dish. 

Wine list was good with several reasonably priced wines by the glass (hard to find in Vegas). Overall good meal and very good service...however I preferred the menu options and atmosphere at Spago, Wolfgang Pucks restaurant at Caesars Palace, to Postrio.

Horrible experience!! Service is slow and food is not properly cooked. I order fetuccini pasta with steak and they overcooked the meat and brought it cold. This restaurant does not provide fine dining, I do not recommend this restsurant to anyone.
Love this Place. :-)
The food takes forever to come. We have been waiting over 45 minutes for 2 burgers. Unbelievable

We arrived hungry and somehow still managed to leave food on our plates (and not because we were stuffed)..

We ordered:
* VEAL OSSO BUCO (Special of the Day)
        - [4/5 - Tender and delicious.]
* DUCK (Special of the Day)
        - [2.5/5 - Mediocre at best.]
* HAND PULLED APPLE STRUDEL w/CARAMEL ICE CREAM
        - [2.5/5 - With "Woflgang's Favorite" in front of it's name, we expected something delicious. It was just alright.. We're both dessert people, and even with sharing, we didn't end up finishing it.]

nice location for having a casual tasty lunch while watching live opera at St. Mark's Square

both dishes i had were very yummy:
* Summer Corn Soup with Roasted Corn and Tomato Relish, Crispy Basil
* Atlantic Salmon with Summer Vegetables, Warm Tomato Vinaigrette, and Basil

If you're a fan of Wolfgang Puck, you must savor the flavors of this awesome restaurant.  I can't think of a better location for Postrio than at St. Mark's Square in the Venetian Hotel, i.e., great food with the romantic ambiance of Venice...minus the expensive flight to the real thing.  

There are two seating options.  You can dine in their formal dining room which is more elegant and intimate or you can opt  for a more casual setting on their patio.  We opted for the patio so we could people watch and sit under the artificially painted blue skys of Italy.  

I'm a big fan of fusion food and I would label this restaurant as an American, Asian, and European fusion restaurant.  What was good here?  Everything we had.  Most notable was the Lobster Club Sandwich.  I know what you're thinking...a sandwich....how good can a sandwich be?  Well, let me tell you...my husband and I had this lobster club 6 years ago and to this day, I still dream about it.  It's that good.  

I long to sink my teeth into another lobster club, but don't think I'll get that opportunity again until my kids are older.  By that time, my teeth would have fallen off and I would have to have it liquidated so I can sip it through a straw.

This is probably one of the most expensive restaurants in Vegas - My appetizer alone was $21.00 for some under cooked risotto (Wild Matsutake Mushroom Risotto, Parmesan Reggiano).  I can make BETTER risotto at home.  I did not bother to complain because I knew there was no point - I just had to survive through my next entree.  My husband had Ravioli with Ricotta, Spinach & Soft Quail Egg, Grilled Quail and Thyme Glaze - it was OK with alot of holiday seasoning.

My dinner entree was Grilled Prime New York Sirloin, Yukon Gold-Horseradish Potatoes, Cognac-Mustard Sauce - $54.00.  I can honestly say the steak was seasoned perfectly and the cognac-mustard sauce was excellent.  My husband had Slow Braised Beef Short Ribs, Creamy Polenta, Olives, Shallots and Natural Juices - not bad either...but then again, how can you screw up short ribs?? Just braise it to death and you'll be OK.

Service was exceptional - don't bother filling up on free bread, try to enjoy your expensive entrees because I didn't finish half my steak and didn't want to carry a doggy bag around :(  

A glass of wine really wasn't a "glass of wine" they poured short of 1/2  a cup a glass...but then again, foo-foo diners don't care when they are carrying wads of money with them.

Skip over to the Gelato stand right next to the restaurant for a cheaper dessert and PLEASE bring your American Express card for this place - don't leave home without it!

If it wasn't for my birthday - I would of gone next door to Enoteca ( I heard their food was great!).

Items Selected:
Mimosa
Double Espresso on Ice
Fresh Pappardelle - Fennel Sausage, Bolognese, Italian Parsley
Bucatini a la Carbonara - Pancetta, English Peas, Parmigiano Reggiano
Breakfast Pizza - Egg, Bacon, Roasted Tomatoes, Spinach, Vermont Cheddar
Warm Brioche Doughnuts - Vanilla, Chocolate, Raspberry
Monkey Bread - Caramel Toffee Sauce, Cream Cheese Sauce
Buttermilk Pancakes - Cinnamon Spiced, Vermont Maple Syrup, Blueberries, Candied Lemon
Pear Sticky Toffee Pudding - Brown Butter Pecan Ice Cream, Spiced Pear Compote
Cinnamon and Dark Chocolate Bread Pudding - Toasted Coconut Ice Cream

Often overlooking Wolfgang Puck restaurants given the Chef's general ubiquity throughout the United States it was at the recommendation of a local writer and with the assistance of Ms. Stephanie Davis of Puck's PR that a reservation was set for brunch at Postrio, and although some of the heavily praised plates from lunch and dinner were not available at brunch while dessert, originally stated as not available was, a noon meal beneath the pseudo-sky of St. Mark's Square at The Venetian proved mostly impressive - the disorganized service and surprisingly loud 'Carnivale' performers aside.

Themed as an informal indoor patio café with a menu covering a handful of WP classics as well as several Italian plates and California-style pizzas it was with complimentary Mimosas that the meal began and offering cheers to an old friend I'd not seen in some time the menu was perused with a three course order originally requested, a fourth only added at the end of the meal when it was revealed that the work of Kamel Guechida was indeed available, an offer I simply couldn't resist.

Joined by an interloping indoor pigeon who was almost as entertaining as the stilt walkers and singers to our side, it was after a long delay that the man who originally served our drinks was finally 'assigned' our table and with the lone special of steak and eggs declined it would not be long before two half-portions of pasta arrived, the wide pappardelle soft and smooth beneath bright tomatoes teaming with aromatic sausage while the al dente round noodles slicked with egg yolk and tossed simply with peas and pork was absolutely textbook, perhaps the best version of the dish served in a resort with no shortage of Italian options from which to choose.

Always amused by Puck's Pizzas, at this point a prerequisite for dining at any of his restaurants, it was with brief consideration of both the mushroom iteration that we opted for the newly added breakfast pie and although I'd have preferred the egg to be served runny after the baking process the general balance of the dish was admirable, a hefty amount of sharp cheddar and bacon most detectable on first bite with the light char notes of crust and vegetal notes lingering on the palate thereafter.

Choosing 'one of each' from the "Batter and Breads" section, suffice it to say that any disappointment regarding soups and sides available only at dinner were mostly forgotten and although the sticky bun was generally underwhelming both in size and in flavor while the stack of cinnamon dusted donuts was far less impressive than those served at Yardbird, the fluffy pancakes with pure maple syrup, blueberries, and candied lemon were absolutely excellent - the $13 price-tag notwithstanding.

Acknowledging that less 'batter' would have been ordered had I known desserts were ready to go it was without batting an eye that two of five delectable sounding options were selected to compliment a double espresso over ice and having last experienced Chef Guechida's work at Joel Robuchon it came as no surprise that the pastry chef's work completely stole the afternoon's spotlight with both the buttery brioche pudding loaded with chocolate beneath intense coconut ice cream and the pear-based sticky toffee cake with pecan studded ice cream the texture of silk absolutely mesmerizing, each elegantly presented and surprisingly restrained in a manner equally befitting the Grand Canal Shoppes or the MGM Grand's 3* crown jewel of the Chef's past.

I had the grilled tuna here...and let me tell you, it was awesome.  The mushroom soup was very good as well....not as creamy as one would expect which made it a nice surprise.  The steak was quite tender and juicy, and the dessert are alllll great except the apple coppler.  The servers were great and constantly refilled your glass of water.  Well enjoyed food.

I have gone hungry to this restaurant twice during happy hour! Both times had great service at the bar! The first time the happy hour small plates are deals but very small portions.  The second time my friend and I shared a burger and fires which was very filling and one of the most delicious ever.  They give you this tasty popcorn at the bar as well. I will treat at this restaurant again!

I've never been a real big fan of any of the Wolfgang restaurants. They were all decent; nothing to really take note of. That all changed this past weekend when I was in Vegas with my wife to celebrate her birthday, our 6 month wedding anniversary, and Valentine's Day. We had made reservations to another place inside the Venetian but since we didn't leave a credit card #, the reservation was cancelled. So we made a reservation at Wolfgang's Postrio which seemed like the only place that had space that evening.

My wife ordered the Seared Sea Scallops and I ordered the Prime Filet Mignon. Both dishes were amazing! The scallops were huge and so tender. But the star of the evening was the Prime Filet Mignon. Holy crap. I've had some great cuts of beef in my lifetime, but this was definitely tops. It was very flavorful and the meat just melted in my mouth. Before this experience, my favorite cut has been at Ruth's Chris Steak House. 

I heard there's a Postrio up in SF too, so now I'm going to have to plan more trips up to SF or Vegas.

Because I couldn't find Brasserie, we ended up at Postrio for lunch the other day.  I was impressed with the nice cafe atmosphere and the menu was smiple enough, so we gave it a try.

We were seated and it took a moment for us to get the server to acknowledge our presence after taking our drink order.  I'm not sure whether he was waiting for us to signal him down, but it took about seven  minutes from our drinks to taking our order.  I was a little frustrated at this, but wanted to give him a second chance and so we ordered our food and waited.

The salad came five minutes after he took our order, two Caesar's,  one without anchovy.  Their salad is baby romaine lettuce stacked on each other with grated cheese, tossed in the dressing and served with one crouton.  The flavors were good and a nice change from the tossed, chopped ones I get at Morels or Golden Steer.  that was 19 dollars.

The food took about 18 minutes after the salads to arrive.  I felt that this was quite long and was trying to flag a server down to ask if they could check for our food.  Either we looked too young to take seriously, or I caught this place on a bad day, but it is still no excuse for the lack of attention we received.  We ran out of water and drinks awhile back and no one checked up on us, so that was a bit frustrating.

When our food did arrive, it was presented well and the portions were a good size.  The large spaghetti was split between my niece and fiance in two separate bowls and looked like a hefty portion, so the 17 dollar price tag was understandable.  The pizza was large as well, about a medium pizza if you order delivery.  The lobster sandwich looked like a good size, too, but instead of a kaiser roll they use toasted grain bread.

Pepperoni, olive and tomato pizza with fresh basil: Good crust, nice taste to the dough as well.  the toppings were lovely and had a nice, salty flavor.  The olives were good and not cooked all the way through, but that was fine for me because I don't mind the texture.  Overall, the pizzas at any Wolfgang's are good.

Spaghetti with meatballs: Five dollars extra for those meatballs, just to warn you.  The pasta is made fresh there, and you can tell by the color and texture of the pasta.  It came roma tomato chunks and lots of cheese, so that was nice.  The sauce had that right amount of tanginess to it and spice.  The meatballs are very good and well flavored.  you still get the meat taste with a hint of Italian spice.  Quite a lovely meal.

Lobster sandwich: Good lobster, very sweet and succulent.  It's a cold sandwich, of course, so the mayo and other ingredients mixed with the lobster were really fresh and light.  The bread is heavy, however, so my husband took the tops off of the halves to avoid getting overfilled.  The fries and skinny fries and are your typical hotel fries.  Overall the sandwich had good flavor but we expected something more.  It almost felt as if this particular dish was missing something, but I couldn't place my finger on it.

For 160 dollars for lunch (I did tip 20% because the service went up from the meal, on) it was okay.  I am not a fan because of the initial service we received, but the food was good.  I like Puck's restaurants, but I won't go out of my way to eat here again.

If you like the cafe feel in Venetian and want something fair and fast, this is the place to go.  I know people are giving it five stars for food, but for my personal taste it wasn't exciting and lacked any "wow" factor that it should have for that price tag.  Still, it's fair eats.

Wow, to compare my experience here this time and my last time in August is the difference between night and day.  It took 30 minutes to receive our drinks (5 minutes before our food came out).  Our server came to the table exactly 3 times - once to take our drink order, once to take our order, then again 15 minutes after our food came out.  The server definitely did *not* get a tip as he didn't deserve one.  Very disappointing considering how much we liked Postrio previously.

It could be so much better. No longer do they serve schnitzel. Good tuna tartare and beet salad. Had a family event and basically no one was impressed. The service was POOR. Pizza soooo disappointing (Wolfgang you need to address this). I heard the bread was good but they must have forgotten to bring it out until one hour into the meal. 
There are many other better places in Vegas.

let's give credit where credit is due.  wolfgang *did* see the potential in vegas w/spago years before emeril, bobby flay, and mario et al from the food network started setting up shop (sigh...and now thomas keller).  

i'm disappointed, as there are too many good restaurants in vegas to demand such high prices for sub-par food riding primarily on a celeb chef's name.  if it weren't for the fact that my girlfriend (local vegas girl) brokered free drinks and meal, plus great service for us, i would've given postrio 1 star.  the food isn't bad, but it is not impressive, far from it.  the GM sat with us for most of our meal and had his exec chef in the kitchen give us special attention throughout the night, but still the food was so-so.  seated near us....a table of 10+ girls, 1 wearing a veil (bachelorette party)...very loud and...well, stereotypical vegas scene.  cheesy.

Loved Postrio!  My halibut was cooked to perfection; crispy on outside, moist on the inside.  Accompanying vegetables (peas, mushrooms) rounded out the dish perfectly.  Fellow diners enjoyed their Caeser salad, steak skewers, and Caprese salad.  The fresh mozzarella was divine.  I expected the angels to sing from the faux-cloud ceiling above.  

Excellent service too!  Thanks guys for making a memorable experience.

I've been here three times now and I will keep coming back when I come to Vegas. The pasta is really good here and chocolate benign is a must try every time. I like how they make simple food and really execute on it. the wait staff have always been really nice as well. the only thing is the price has really gone up from my recent trip, $24 for spaghetti and meatball. seriously?

We came to Postrio for lunch and sat outside to enjoy the Carnevale performances in St. Marks Square.  We started with a tomato bisque soup with a sweet corn fritter - out of this world!  The items we selected for lunch were a simpler turkey sandwich and scrambled egg pizza.  The pizza dough has a very slight sweetness from honey and the roasted turkey sandwich was on house made bread and came with some unique potato chips.   We will definitely be back.  Maybe for dinner next time to really experience more things like that soup!

Be patient while your food is cooking and you shall know what I mean.  The food is just awesome and not overly-priced. We went there on a Sunday, about 1pm and sat outside so we get to enjoy the free shows at the plaza... ahhhh "Venice, Italy" atmosphere.  I don't exactly remember what my friends ordered but we all shared our food and i must say, the "baked apple pancake" is a must.  Mango Peach smoothie was so yummy too! Staff is so friendly, too. =)

Stopped in here a while ago for dinner with the family while staying at the Venetian. Didn't look like much from the outside, but I was taken aback by the classy interior. 

Server was very professional, no pens or pads, got to know us and gave us detailed descriptions of all the specials and anything we asked. I ended up ordering some sort of boiled spinach salad and the filet mignon. Though pricey at around $50, I felt it was worth it. It was fired at a high temperature with a salt/pepper crust and the inside was bloody as hell, just like I ordered. Was topped with caramelized onions and had a side of yukon gold mashed potatoes which were very well-made. Although there are other places I would dine at in Vegas before this one, it's definitely worth stopping by and shelling out a few bucks if you find yourself in the hotel.

I love how you feel like you're outdoors here but you're really indoors!

My friends and I came here on the sole fact that it was cheaper than it's neighboring Italian joint.  

I ordered a pizza and had some of my friends' pecan pancakes with cinnamon.  Hands down, best pancakes I have ever had in my entire life.  It must have been hat maple syrup or the nice size of the pancakes.  I am feigning for those pancakes!

i've had the salmon entree on a few occasions and it never disappoints. i enjoy a glass of wine and sitting "outside" by the shops...

beyond humorous people watching.

My wife and I found this restaurant while walking through the Venetian.  Located in St. Mark's Square, it has a nice open air type of atmosphere.

We ordered Kumamoto oysters as appetizers.  The oyster were fresh and delicious.  I had the mushroom tortellini and that was very good.  The sauce was probably the best part of the dish.  My wife had pan fried scallops.  The scallops were perfectly cooked, but my wife was not too fond of the sauce that came with it.  In fact, she started dipping her scallops in my sauce.  All in all, nice ambiance and good food.  We'll definitely not hesitate to return here.

Surprised to see so many negative reviews.  The service here was amazing, the food was awesome, and the Long Island Ice Tea was bomb.  I mean seriously, who actually likes the taste of a long island ice tea?  I bought it because I was short on cash and the meal was kind of pricey, but that drink was GOOD!

My friend and I chose this restaurant to eat at before a performance of Phantom. We had noticed that they were offering a discount off the bill total if you were seeing the show that day. (25% off). Unfortunately, the ad and the reservationist forgot to mention that in order to receive the discount, the server needs to keep your show tickets, so you're only suppose to eat there after the performance. After talking with the manager, and I mentioned he could make photocopies of the tickets, he then decided to make photocopies. Also, we weren't the only ones dining on the patio to have this problem. They were also giving a local discount, and my friend happened to be local, so we received an added bonus. The food is good and the wait staff are pleasant. I just wished they had told us everything before we arrived, but at least the manager did right, but we had to talk to him for 10 minutes. And if you sit on the patio you can hear/watch the Venetian performers perform.

Unfortunately Postrio has taken a turn for the worse. We ordered a tuna tartare appetizer which was decent. 

My girlfriends gnocchi was decent but the lobster in my lobster club was rotten. My girlfriend needed to pick up some immodium after our visit and almost vomited while in the restaurant. Postrio is down for the count!! What happened!? This used to be a regular stop for us. NO MORE!!

Postrio should get the award for the messiest burger on the Strip. Good, but messy! 

As you can tell, I ordered the burger (Grilled Black Angus Burger, Vermont Cheddar Cheese, Onion Marmalade, Fries) for lunch. It was quite good, well-cooked to medium, and messy as all heck thanks to the onion marmalade. I was just happy I wasn't on a first date trying to eat the thing! Dripping onion marmalade everywhere - all over the plate, down my fingers and hand, you get the idea.

The fries were yummy, too.

"patio" seating puts you outside the restaurant, but still indoors in the artificial venetian outdoors - beautiful "weather" and lots of people-watching to do hah!  every hour they have a live performance, so we enjoyed a violinist performance for most of our dinner - very beautiful atmosphere!

the food was great:
1) prime rib burger which hit the spot.  
2) pork schnitzel reminded of thin pork katsu.. it was good, but probably would not order it again - didn't have a 'wow' factor
3) housemade pepperoni pizza was delicious -!

excellent service, and definitely an enjoyable dinner!

I'm not going to lie: we were here with a large group (19 people) and in a rush to head over to the Marquee (or was it Tao?).

Between us all, we probably ordered 4-5 pizzas and I only got to try one: the typical BBQ chicken.  Was it good?  Yes.  Amazing for a Wolfgang Puck restaurant?  Maybe, maybe not.  It didn't blow me away like I thought it would, but maybe we should have gotten something else.

Of course, the ambiance is great in the Venetian.  We were sat outside next to the bar and got pretty decent service -- except my friend who sat in a corner behind a pillar got skipped over his water a couple times, but it's forgivable.

Moral of the story: don't get a pizza at higher end places.

If you like, it seems like they have smaller, quieter seating behind glass doors.

Had a corporate private dinner in the back room. There was a limited menu where most items were not on the normal menu. I the rack of lamb, a pumpkin soup, salad, and Tiramisu. The soup was so-so, salad was average and the Tiramisu was good but the portion was so small I'd barely call it a tasting. BUT the Rack of Lamb was PERFECT. The portion size was very good, it was cooked perfectly, and tasted above average. The service was good, to be expected since it was a corporate event. I'd go back.

freakin wolfgang man! the thing that keeps me comming back is the LOBSTER CLUB! its only available during lunch hours... cuts off at 5 but it is the best freakin sandwich on the planet. comes on some type of multi grain bread, which is not hard at all and is just phenomenal. i will pay $30 for the damn sandwich over and over again b/c it is that good.

esspresso shots are good at the bar, good wine and appetizers are good too.

there used to be a meatball appetizer with sundried tomatoes that was out of this world, but they took it off the menu, i dont know why :(

HIGHLY RECOMMENDED AS ONE OF MY FAVORITES IN VEGAS!

This place was alright. We were able to get last minute reservations on a Monday night.

Atmosphere was great. Very Modern.

Pasta was pretty good.  All of there pasta is made fresh daily, so I would stick to this when ordering. My boyfriend got the Mushroom Raviloi, and it was pretty good.

Chicken Picattta was disappointing. For a $26, I don't think it was worth it. It was basically a breaded and fried chicken breast with very little sauce. Served with fingerling potatoes and spinach. I was so hungry and ate most of it, but the whole time was thinking, we totally make his dish better at home.

Service was okay. We felt like our server was being a bit condosending with the answers to our questions. That was a disappointment as well, but that was just one server. The other servers who helped us out were great.

We probably won't be back since there are so many other places to eat in Vegas, but if you're looking for some good, freshly made pasta at the Venetian, this would be the place to go
The tuna tartare was to die for!!.. I will come here again just for that!. We sat "outside" and the ambiance was nice to people watch and enjoy live music. Our waitress was nice but she was so slow.

it's been a while since I've had something that should be considered "higher end".  For a saturday night, the service was extremely fast and the waitstaff friendly.  While the food itself was not of the "blow your mind" variety, it definitely is a step up from your average chain restaurant.  I had the wine infused oxtail with herb papperdelle noodles, asparagus, and wild mushrooms.  Also present at dinner were a mushroom broccolini pizza and a Burata cheese ravioli.

The oxtail dish was good - hearty but not overly so and the wine sauce paired decently with the herbed pasta and the mushrooms. There was something missing to the dish though - each component by itself was tasty, but the dish in toto was only good, not outstanding.  Overall not so disappointing as to offend, but not so spectacular as to prevent some slight regrets for not ordering the ciopinno instead.  

The pizza stood much better as a whole experience, though the dough reminded me too much of pita and also too much of how delicious the crust at pizza delfina is in comparison. 

The burrata (burata?  am I even remembering what the name of this cheese is?) ravioli was the crown jewel of the meal, IMO, mainly because of the cheese itself.  Smooth and buttery without holding too much liquid or falling apart, this cheese may be my new favorite, even compared to the uncomparable bufalo (if not simply because I love saying Bufalo :D).    There was a strong garlic flavor to the accompanying red sauce.  

Both the ravioli and the papperdelle were rather al dente, perhaps overly so for freshly made pasta, but still tasty enough for me to finish.

I would come back for lunch if staying at the palazzo or ventian in the future.

Postrio really is about as good as it gets.  The wine list is impeccable, the appetizers - and salads are fresh and unique - we had oysters on the half shell that were fresh and amazing.  The unique salad blends were great - the goat cheese crostini that accompanied the mixed greens was good enough to be an app itself!!  The Olive tray was sinful -  almost as sinful as the bread bowl!  

The entrees were varied - and all 8 of our diners were thrilled with their choices - from Veal to sea bass and steak.  My sea bass fell apart when lightly touched - and was sweet and delicious!  

A cheese plate (they added a few chocolates for fun) is always a favorite on the menu - a nice touch I think - and when asked to please rid it of blue cheese - they easily complied.  All in all - add in the Bellagio Fountains providing a visual display every 30 minutes - attentive - non-pretentious staff  - and it really is a restaurant experience that does not disappoint.

While I enjoy a few other Wolfgang Puck restaurants this one is just terrible.
They messed up our order on more then one occasion.

I ordered the "Pink Lady Apple Salad, Arugula, Fennel, Medjool Dates, Shropshire Blue Cheese, Aged Sherry Vinaigrette " for the start. I specifically asked if they could exchange the Arugula for a crisper green such as Romaine or Butter Lettuce and they assured me it would be no problem. Well, my salad came and it had Arugula. I brought it to the waiters attention and he did say they messed up and would re-make it right except by the time the new salad came so did my steak.  It would turn out that I had time to eat the newer salad because the "Rib Eye Steak" I ordered well done came out rare.
I just didn't enjoy my meal or the service. For what you pay in this restaurant you would expect that what you order would come out right.
Well, for the both of our meals it came out to $120 before tip.
I recommend not wasting your money here.

This place is very spacious and nice looking place. Location is good and is attractive set up. They loose a star because the chair on the outside are so incredibly uncomfortable i left with my back hurting :( so sit on the inside or bar. The food was very tasty, one of the better spaghetti and meatballs iv had in a while. Also tasted there pizza. which was so super delicious! It is a must get. Prices are average cant complain. Would return.

Food quality is why the 4 star rating, but I would rate the service only 3 stars because our Italian waiter forgot 3 things: my wine order (was supposed to be served before appetizer), bread bowl refill and water glass top-offs (we had to ask twice). Even tlthough he had a nice personality, he was so distracted & scatter-brained during the whole dinner! My husband wanted to leave only a 5% tip, but I left my usual 15% for the sake of posterity. The food was excellent enough to put up with the no-good waiter, though.

When I saw they had a lobster club sandwich on the menu, I thought I was in heaven. Unfortunately, I would discover that lobster and bacon don't really go well together. The bacon totally overpowered the lobster and the sandwich was a drippy mess with the tomatoes & sauces. The nine-grain bread they used didn't go well with the lobster either. The side of french fries on the other hand was delicious! I love my fries thin & crisp and lightly seasoned :)

I went during brunch time since they were advertising free mimosas and missed out on the coveted donuts!

They gave us apple fritters instead which were perfectly lightly crunchy on the outside and so doughy on the inside filled with apples which were still slightly crunchy and not too sour. It came with an interesting apple paste spread as well as a creamy sauce on the plate which I preferred.

We also got monkey bread which was so perfectly sticky with a bit of crunchy texture inside. It's a bit on the sweeter side but didn't verge on TOO sweet for me. This was definitely my favorite of the two. 

I'd be interested in trying entrees here in the future!

This restaurant is in the middle of "San Marcos Square" in the Venetian.  Yes, the square is kinda cool, it looks a little bit like the real thing.  Postrio is nice, the hostess was absolutely a charmer.  Service was great.

I had the rib eye salad special, which was nice.  The appetizer was a gazpacho that was advertised to be more like a soup with lots of interesting things in it, such as panzanilla.  It ended up being gazpacho in a large bowl with about 2 tablespoons of things in the middle, including bread crumbs.  Too much tomato, which was rather plain, and not enough of the interesting things in it.

This is a terrific place to eat. The lobster club is excellent, as is the many kinds of sausage platter and the gnocchi is yummy. The people-watching on the terrace is always fun, and the service is always skilled and professional. We always stop in here when in Vegas and we are always glad we made the point to come (we don't stay at the Venetian because the "suites" aren't real suites.)  But I wish Postrio would put the lasagna back on the menu. It was the lasagna of your dreams, unlike any you have ever eaten in your life, and I will never ever stop wishing that they would return it to the menu.

We went to Postrio on our last night in Vegas. We usually have lunch at Spago once during our trips to town, but decided to try Postrio for dinner instead. We wanted a simple meal and I ordered the caprese salad to start and practically licked the plate! My husband had the crab cakes, which were delicious. We shared the best pizza I've ever eaten. Wow, it was so good!  And to end the meal we had the mango souffle with raspberry sauce which was extraordinary! I'm still thinking about that dessert a week later! The wait staff was professional and attentive, we sat "outside" on the patio, which while noisy, is a fun place to people watch.  Go there and enjoy.

Enjoyable "patio" setting in the fake St. Mark's Square with reasonable prices but abysmal service and mediocre food. To their credit, the manager apologized profusely for the service and discounted the bill.

Been here a couple times, and while Wolfgang Puck isn't on my superfave chefs list, I have found that this particular restaurant of his is kind of a lunch standby for us when other places let us down (*cough cough* MB across the way *cough cough*).  

The salmon burger, when they have it, is outstanding.  We've tried a few pizzas and those were good too (I think there was a duck one that I really liked).  The most recent visit we had a butter lettuce caesar salad that was delightful, a lobster club sandwich (lobster was a little hidden by the mayo and other flavors unfortunately) and the lasagna.  For dessert we had the new (it was only the first day or so they were offering it) "Wolfgang's childhood favorite" apple struedel (I think?) with a scoop of caramel gelato.  THAT was definitely the best thing of the meal, complete with drunken ginormous raisins.  Ask for a knife though, otherwise you'll destroy the beautiful phyllo layers while you're trying to get a bite.  

The food here is better than average, but don't come expecting to be blown away.  It's a solid pick, and a pretty good deal--especially if you get a 20% coupon for staying at the Venetian or Palazzo!  

I will say that on both our visits the service has been phenomenal.  Every detail done to make us feel special and well-attended to.  Kudos to our waiter (wish i could remember his name!) and the rest of the staff.

I can't believe this restaurant has been in my hood of SF all this time and I had to go all the way to Vegas to finally try it.  All I have to say is Molto Bene!  Everything was perfect.

My collective dinner dates of 16 girls all got pizza with the exception of me.  When I tasted the margherita with it's perfect bites of basil and savory mozzerella I thought, "Damn, I'm so stupid to come to an Italian restaurant and not order pizza".  The crusts were buttery, slightly sweet, and had an even golden color all around - I would liken it to a fancy version of CPK's.  I also tried the chorizo (might as well be thick pepperoni) and basil shrimp (delish!).  

I was feeling a little stupid for not getting something super Italian and carb-y but I relented when I saw my dish come out. The caprese salad with heirloom tomatoes and burrata cheese was drool-inducingly amazing.  Watery, cold, and creamy burrata over juicy, firm and ridiculously red tomatoes - a sweet balsamic drizzle over the plate - holy moly, I was so glad I ordered what I did.  It was light and cool - excellent for a hot Vegas night.

We were staying at the Venetian and found ourselves famished. A quick check on Yelp and we found this place. We called down first to see how long the wait would be and the women who answered said they were slow and there would be no wait. What a difference 15 minutes makes! We get down there and all of a sudden there is a 1/2 hour wait. That was a rather crappy start to an otherwise delicious meal.  We sat "outside" which is really the inside, but with the view of St. Marks square (the Venetians replica). The service was spot on, the food was delicious and there was live music being played in St. Marks square.  We ended our meal with the chocolate beignets, they were amazing.  We also split the cheesecake which was far less impressive.  Yummy mea overall!

You must absolutely get the Truffled Potato Chips with Bleu Cheese.

Everything else we ordered was pretty good but that initial appetizer blew our minds. We got a couple pizzas and the burger on the menu. Again, anything and everything was good in terms of quality and presentation.

I'm taking off 1 star from this place because the service is extremely slow. You might as well wear pajamas and take a nap because it takes like 7 hours to get your meal. It wasn't even busy in the restaurant either when I was there.

man oh man oh man.... this place is sooo good.  Its why I continue to go back.  This time out I had some spicy tuna tartare to start and my friend had the truffel and bleu cheese home-made chips... delish!    I had a few johnnie black and sodas then out came my striped bass (fish of the day) order over some delicious fresh veggies, some sort of mushroom sauce and a tad of potatoes....   man was this good... i actually ate the fish painfully slow, because I didnt want it to be all gone.  Its like it wasnt fair that it was going to be gone in a few minutes - lol -  I really wish I could afford to eat here every night -- and by afford I mean calories... that was my cheat meal of the week.... Silly diets  :)      But, I know I will go back because this place is just far too good not to.  see ya soon Postrio.

Amazing!  Prices might be on steep side but you could pay the same elsewhere for bad food. EVERYTHING we ordered was delectable!

Oysters on half shell was fresh and tasty. Even an 11 year old slurped them up! Caesar salad scrumptious, fresh and tasty light. The kid took more of salad off my plate, YES!!! Must be good! Kid loved spaghetti and meatballs and devoured the bread..this is a kid who is normally a finicky light eater.  Ciopinno for adults was fall down awesome!  Made a normal gym rat light eater ecstatic to splurge on this absolutely clean, fresh and tasty dish and sad to have to leave leftovers due to being so full.  WOW. Service awesome and attentive.
Very good food and service, pleasant ambience sitting under the air-conditioned "sky" of Venice at a simulated sidewalk cafe.  Server really knew his wines.

Nice atmosphere, Greek salad is light and refreshing, calamari was a little over breaded, catch of the day (seabass) was cooked great, clams linguini was decent but nothing to write home about. Finally the sangria was very nice and the chocolate souffle seemed overly decadent when being put together at the table, but it turned out to have a great combination of flavors.

Our waiter Michael was molto benne!

We went back to Postrio for lunch and it was just as good as dinner! 

There were about 10 things on the menu we both wanted to try. He got a Reuben sandwich and I got a crazy meat pizza with jalapenos. Lots of meat and lots of jalapenos - it got super spicy. 

Its nice to sit "outside" and people watch - this is a really good place to eat in Vegas.

Las Vegas food critic John Curtas (KNPR) picked Postrio as restaurant of the year for 2004, and named one of Postrio's dishes the best entre of 2005.  A member of the Wolfgang Puck stable, Postrio says it serves contemporary American cuisine, such as steaks, seafood, and those most quintessential of American foods: Italian pastas and pizzas.  Dinner is available in the informal cafe or the more formal dining room; lunch is available only in the cafe.  I opted for lunch.

The menu varies according to location (dining room or cafe) and meal (lunch or dinner).  The lunch menu offers such choices as pork wienerschnitzel, Hungarian goulash, and a lobster club sandwich, as well as pizza and pasta.

Lunch is served in the "outdoor" cafe portion of the restaurant.  It's open to the shopping area and trompe l'oeil sky.  The background noise level is generally not bad, but it gets a bit much when nearby performers start singing.

I ordered pork wienerschnitzel, Austrian potato salad, and whole grain mustard sauce.  It was a thin but obscenely large piece of pork - about 7" by 10" - crisp and not greasy.  A lemon provided needed acidity, and the mustard sauce was mild but had good flavor.  All in all, a good combination.  On the other hand, the potato salad was bland.  I was pleased with my lunch, but it wasn't anything spectacular.  Perhaps I'll need to give it another try at dinner time.

It's been awhile back since my last visit to Postrio, I don't even remember what I had for dinner here, obviously it wasn't memorable enough.  But I'll never forget the doting service, delicious bread basket, attention to detail (wipe crumbs off the table and the waitstaff iron the tablecloths when it's changed) and that glorious chocolate souffle.  It's incredibly fluffy and soft texture kept my head in the clouds for a good part of my trip. It's at least a 30 minute wait for the souffle so place your order ahead of time.
I had a Fettuccini Alfredo and I was disappointed... This is a wast of money... I thought  Wolfgang Puck , the famous chef would have better tasting dishes....

This was very mediocre. Let me say first that I even had a coupon for 25% off my meal and it was not worth it. I mean, anywhere else, I'd say meh... it was ok. But this is Vegas. And since this trip I only had 2 days, every meal counts. 

I ordered a sandwich (some sort of club) and the onion soup. The onion soup was sweet enough to be a dessert... imagine French onion soup without the saltiness nor cheese and throw on spoonfuls of sugar. Not very appetizing, right? The fries that came with my sandwich were also quite cold. I could literally see into the kitchen from my table. I saw my sandwich made, and it didn't take that long to come out. So why were my fries cold? They must have been from an old batch.

As far as service, it was decent. Friendly waiter, but not enough to save the whole restaurant. I sat inside (outside was a longer wait). The atmosphere outside (I say outside loosely...since it is in the middle of the Venetian) would probably have been a better experience. 

Not going to return, though, considering there were other restaurants in the same square.

This review is for a private party banquet, as the bride and groom chose this venue for their hosted engagement dinner. Postrio was solid food and very attentive staff.

The waiters were constantly making their rounds to serve the hor d'oeuvres and the dining room was more than large enough to house all 60 guests. 

For our tasting menu, we enjoyed several variations of gourmet pizzas, lamp chop lollipops, crab cakes and lobster cakes. For dinner, we had a choice of either seafood cioppino or a rib eye steak with pureed mashed potatoes and vegetables. The rib eye was tender, juicy and flavorful, the mashed potatoes were creamy, soft and fluffy and the veggies included a tasty assortment of asparagus, broccoli rabe and carrots. 

Our friends have great taste - everything was delicious! I'd love to come back and try more of their menu.

Excellent dining spot in St Marks Sq of the Venetian. 

I started with a delicious Ceasar salad with wonderfully tangy white anchovies. Followed by a pizza with homemade pepperoni ... when a Wolfgang Puck restaurant of this quality makes pizza you know it will be good ... and it was!

Service was excellent, friendly but classy (i.e not in your face every 5 minutes asking 'are you still doing ok?' as if we are all near death!).

I would return in a heartbeat.

P.S The wine was very good value too!

Eh, for a Wolfgang Puck restaurant, the food at Postrio was underwhelming.  The meatball pizza was...just ok.  When ordering, our waiter did mention that their tomato sauce was amazing...and it WAS good.  But, I found the meatballs to be too soft and semi-crumbly.  The white/veggie pizza was also ok, but a little bland.  The truffle potato chips were a win, though!  Very tasty and fresh!  

The big draw for this restaurant, though, is that you are eating "outside" in the Ventatian's replica of St. Mark's Square.  That in itself is probably the best part of this experience.  Since you're outside, you can people watch or take in one of the fun shows that are going on out there.  It's fun for all ages!  The service here is absolutely lovely and friendly, too.  Our waiter didn't smirk when my dad ordered a Reuben without the sauerkraut, rye bread and thousand island dressing.  That takes alot of skill right there.

I've been here twice, on two travels to Sin City. The food was pretty good.  I got the fish once.  This came wrapped in parchment paper.  I felt the lemon was a little overpowering because it was a light tilapia.  This was a long time ago and I thought that it was not up to Wolfgang Puck standards, in my head.

This time, I got the pizza.  It was thin and light but I feel I could've gotten that at any other location.  It was a delicious pizza but it was on the same level as places not owned by Wolfgang Puck.

All in all, it was ok.

Calamari was too salty.  Pizza was good.  Disappointed that the coupon for "bar bites" was only applicable at the bar.  Figures.  Vegas is full of "bait and switch" deals.  The Venetian/Palazzo which is a pretty good hotel should not need to mislead.

Usually I go to Otto which is right across Postrio. It's the new year, let's give this place a try. It's brunch time and they offered free mimosa. I informed the waiter that I don't drink alcohol and is there non alcoholic option- iced tea, orange juice, etc. It's not complimentary so I ordered iced tea. This was a turn off that they didn't provide non alcoholic option which is cheaper for them actually. Menu options looks very appealing. I love Wolfgang's restaurants especially the one in Beverly Hill and LA.  Looking forward to seeing how it is in this Las Vegas place. Corned beef hash with egg was quite yummy. Almost ordered desert but mostly chocolate. Good for those who loves chocolate. I don't so I passed on.

My mom and I actually had dinner plans with a big group of family at another restaurant, but we were tired and hungry from shopping so we stopped in for drinks and appetizers. Her pear martini was unbelievable: so fresh, not too sweet, and garnished with a slice of pear on top. I had a Moscow mule, which was tasty but nothing special. However, the real star was the appetizer. We went with the cheese board, and it was incredible (and $20): three kinds of cheese, apples, walnut toast, a few jams and some honey. 

The pizza also looked great, and the fries with garlic aioli. I wish we could have gone back for a full meal. However, be careful because the prices add up: our two drinks plus a cheese board was almost $50 total. A splurge, but worth it!

Staying at the Venetian they give you a $25.00 food credit to this place so we decided to give it a try.
Staff was very busy and the service was pretty bad, waited 40 minutes to get appetizers then our dinners followed right behind.  First of all we wait forever just to get apps then have to hurry to eat them so they can put the main course down, Wolfgang would have had a fit if he saw that go down!! No apology's were made.
Now I do have to say that the mussels where some of the best I have ever eaten but the clam linguine was extremely bland and the clams were so fishy tasting that I picked them out. I think they were suppose to offer fresh parmigian over our pasta which could have made a big difference. Shrimp pizza was just ok, you would expect it to blow you away! My daughter really enjoyed the spaghetti and meatballs. The cesear salad had excellent flavor however I'm not a fan of the lettuce being whole leaf, I would rather they cut it up but this is just a personal preference so you decide. The asparagus soup was pretty tasty and the chocolate soufflé was excellent along with the ice cream they serve with it however you need more ice cream. The ratio of cake to ice cream was waaaaay off! Also I was expecting very high quality drinks based not only on the price but the other review where the guy said the moscow mule was the best. I've been a bartender for years and these were just not up to my personal standard. The pineapple juice was not fresh nor was there fresh ginger in the moscow mule. Small effort to make a huge difference in a cocktail!
All in all I would not return to Postrio except maybe for the mussels and some water!!! The mussels were that good!!

Ended up in Postrio during my most recent Vegas trip. After getting over a bit of sticker shock, the meal was really enjoyable. The food was delicious, and the service was prompt and friendly even though my friends and I are unmanageable jackasses when we get together in the best of circumstances and had all been drinking.

This is one my my husband and my favorite places in Vegas.  We came upon this place a few months ago, loved it, and have returned every single visit to Vegas since.  (Yes, we do go that often).

Our initial, life changing meal there consisted of proscuitto wrapped cantaloupe with figs, meat lasagna, and beignets.  OUT OF THIS WORLD!  (in fact, I just realized I reviewed this meal back in June 2010.  Ha ha).

This Wolfgang Puck restaurant changes its menu every so often, so we haven't been able to recreate this meal since, but we haven't been disappointed.

This visit, we brought my brother, and we all shared several portions of the lobster sandwich, field greens, and short rib ravioli.  The lobster sandwich was amazing.  Would do this again.  The ravioli was a little salty, but as authentic and homecooked as you can get.  Like it really tastes like the short ribs were perfectly braised, separated from the bones, and stuffed into the pasted right before they brought it out...  

Of course, we got the beignets.  Yummy donuts filled with chocolate, that literally explodes in your mouth.  Watch out.  Comes with coffee ice cream.  I love it.

The restaurant is located right in the center of the shopping area between the Venetian ad Palazzo, where there are intermittent shows and singing.  Really fun atmosphere to enjoy dinner.

Found ourselves in the Venetian around dinner time, and between the three main restaurants in the St. Mark's area, this one seemed to be the best bet!

We didn't regret the decision, as the entire experience was both relaxing and pleasant. Instead of sitting in the weird outside vibes area, we dined inside, where it was dark but quiet. We even had a little fireplace by us, and it was eerie to see the glow of the fake outside world through the doors.

Despite service being a bit confusing at times (our main waiter was slow, and we had two other people asking us for our orders at different periods), things came out timely and well cooked. My boyfriend and I shared the creamy potato leek soup which was definitely creamy and not too potato-like, but still good when served with the crunchy bread. 

Vegetarian fare was plain & simple - homemade pasta with a mushroom cream sauce. I'm used to this. Still a classic dish, and done great with some mini onions and a myriad of different mushrooms. It was definitely not salted enough so I asked my server, who was a bit taken aback, for a bit of salt. My boyfriend went nuts over the meatloaf & onion rings dish! I was happy about his excitement! :)

The dessert menu rocked!! I don't even know where to begin. I was so confused - definitely a huge hardship for the night. I chose the lemon pudding cake with blueberry compote & blueberry gelato, which was maybe my only mistake - a little too lemony/sweet, overpowering. I wish I had gotten the sweet potato pie! Oh well :) A very great meal! Slow and delicious, definitely filing & reasonably priced.

This place was awful. I ordered the salt and pepper calamari.  Little did I know that they were going to put the whole container of salt on it. It was so salty, I couldn't eat it and I like my food pretty salty. I was so disappointed. My friend ordered the Cuban sandwich and said it lacked flavor. My water tasted like tap water. The service was extremely slow. I was quiet disappointed. I guess I should have checked yelp first. Needless to say, I'm never coming back here.

Went to the cafe, which is the patio area.

Fried parmesan risotto balls - 4 small fried balls (about 1 inch each) with tomato sauce.  It was pretty good but I don't think I would order it again.
Crispy shrimp, calamari, olive and zucchini - sooooo good.  The batter was seasoned and very lightly coated onto the ingredients.
Prosciutto pizza - fresh tasting...can be a bit salty with the olives.  I liked how the prosciutto was spread out and cut into little pieces as opposed to a huge pile in the middle of the pizza.
Porcini mushroom ravioli - very fresh mushrooms.
Flirtini martini - fruity, a little strong but good.

Total came out to be $72.  I would go again...it's a nice place to people watch.

Excellent food, especially the caramelized onion pizza. When we had an issue with one of the oysters in our appetizer not smelling right, they replaced it.   My husband and I thoroughly enjoyed our dining experience, including great service. It wasn't our first time dining there and it won't be our last.
Great stop waiting for a concert to start. Friendly staff, good drinks!

The entire decor and the menu of Postrio have both recently been remodeled, changing the vibe to an upscale bar and sophisticated grill. This has made a world of difference (I was never impressed with the restaurant prior to this change). This was our second time coming back since it's been re-done, and while everything is very good, a few items particularly stood out.

The Korobuta pork schnitzel with Austrian potatoes and whole grain mustard sauce that my dad ordered was fantastic (my husband and I had it last time), and is one of Puck's personal comfort foods so worth trying. The pork is pounded thinly and lightly pan fried, and rests on a bed of lemon and herb dressed fingerling potatoes. It is also served with a cooling cucumber yogurt sauce and mini sald of teardrop tomatoes. There is nothing wrong with this dish at all, and I can't imagine it being any better in Puck's home country. There was nothing wrong with my husband's dish either, which unfortunately was only a special for the evening. This was a large portion of two perfectly roasted quail served on a bed of fluffy gnocchi and freshly shucked spring peas, bathed in a rich and intensely flavored reduction. This should become a permanet fixture on the menu because it really was amazing. My entree of steamed black mussels with white wine, garlic, grilled sourdough lavishly spread with bernaise was very good, but somewhat disappointing in comparison to the version at his restaurant, Spago, in Beverly Hills. At Spago the mussels were petite and sweet, making it unique from other versions of steamed mussels, and the bernaise was prepared with a bit more skill. It's hard for me to evaluate the mussels here without thinking of the mussels there, so while the comparison was fun, I'd order something else next time.

The appetizers we had were good but I wasn't nearly as impressed with those as I was with the entrees. We had the mesquite grilled steak skewers with creamy celery salad and house made steak sauce, and the charcuterie plate with grilled bread, artisan cheese, and marinated olives. The former was good but didn't taste terribly original (the little salad was the best part) and the latter was missing a sweet element and could have used some work on the presentation. I understood from a business perspective that they were trying to make it look like a huge portion, but I prefer something that looks a little less like a deli tray when I order charcuterie. 

I forgot to write down the prices, and they aren't showing up online (I hate when restaurants hide this), but I can assure you Postrio is pricey. My advice would be to skip on the apps (or at least those that we got), get an entree, and limit your drinks if you want to experience the restaurant without breaking the bank. Oh, and eat lots of bread - it's fantastic.

Everything was wonderful!  Service, food, ambiance.

Lunch crowd is more casual, and you can witness the "street entertainment".

We ordered so much food and a variety, for that matter.  Everything will taste wonderful!  It's WP, for god's sake.

Bloody Mary's - GREAT.

Service was above and beyond! Free mimosas for the entire bachelorette party:)
Super attentive and nice!

I've been eating here for years. Every time I go to Vegas I eat here. Last night my dinner was very disappointing. The cheese ravioli was soooo salty. My friend's salmon was above average, but not up to par with Wolfgang Puck's name. I bragged about how great the place was, but was not a good dining experience. The water was not cold. And the wait staff was blah. The mgr comped my meal, but I would much rather preferred to have great food and pay for it.  The mgr was deadpan like the wait staff.

3.5 stars

decent, italian fare. i loved my pasta, had a wonderful drink or five and had a great dinner.

i would go back if at the venetian. sitting on that courtyard is just so awesome!

Disappointed. Overpriced. We had lunch here in the st. Mark squares in venetian hotel. Atmosphere on patio is exquisite. 

However, food is so so. Milk shakes was good. Had some kind of grilled sea bass. nothing special. I Guess I Am ComplaininG due to price I paid for it.

Just went to one of my favorite places in Vegas this past weekend.  I was disappointed that they changed their menu a bit.  Not as much pasta dishes as before, and the pizza choices were not as good too.  I had to lower my rating from 5 star to 4 star because of this.  They were also out of a couple of wines on the wine list which was disappointing.

Great atmosphere, service, and food!

My general opinion of restaurants on the strip is that they are overpriced and overrated.  The atmosphere of sitting in St. Marks square in the patio area was a big hit with my elderly grandparents and the waiter was very patient and professional with them. I was very happy with the meatloaf;  For $19 I got Wolfgang Puck's delicious gourmet take on the classic comfort food.  My wife had the lobster ravioli and was very happy with it.  Recommend getting reservations if you want to sit out on the patio.  

I thoroughly enjoyed the dining experience at Postrio and would definitely go back for more.

We went on a Sunday late afternoon and we were a group of about 19.  Took the whole back area near bar.  Restaurant was not full but waitstaff took forever  to bring menus and take drink orders.  They had a happy  hour menu of bite size appetizers.  For example of sliders were microscopic  smallest burgers  I have ever seen.  Food is on the pricey side for amount you get. we had the margherita pizza, calamari were just okay and the ariisanal cheese selection with fig spread was good. Was really not good for groups we had to split our group into sections even though we took up most of the back bar area. Service was slow.

One often hears a rendition of the famous adage to enjoy the journey rather than to rush through it, and this is one prime example of such great advice.
We were intrigued by the 1000 plus reviews for Bouchon, so our aim was to dine at this establishment for brunch.  However, i couldn't muster any more energy to walk that extra 10 minutes through the windy Venetian Hotel, so we ended up at Postrio instead.  MUST.EAT. NOW.  lol.  this was an amazing gem with prime real estate seating.  

LUNCH FARE: 

RICOTTA GNOCCHI with Sweet Fennel Sausage Bolognese ($25)
a soft ballad of flavors dance together with each bite.  so soft with potatoes oozing out.  each bite was outstanding and just the perfect portion.

TRIO OF HOUSE MADE SAUSAGES ($16)
Housemade Mustard, Pickled Vegetables, Grilled Country Bread, Baby Mache.  
yes, appetizer portion, but i knew i had to save room for dessert.  my ideal type of meal is usually 60% protein, 30% veggies, and 10% carbs, and this dish delivers exactly that.  executed so well, each bite was heavenly.  the sausage on the far right had pistachios, so pistachio lovers -- make note.  the fuchsia looking vegetable adjacent to the pistachio sausage is actually pickled watermelon.   it's not the typical watermelon that one would purchase at the local market.  this type of melon had the tight texture & consistency of a daikon or a radish, yet it was a watermelon.  

CHOCOLATE MELTING BEIGNETS were fabulous! ($12)
the chocolate beignets were oozing with warm chocolate filling and dusted with powdered sugar.  one proper spoonful of ice cream  was the perfect complement to the warm beignet.  the vanilla dipping sauce was just an icing to the dish -- it was great, but not necessary, but definitely did not hurt it at all.  for a dessert, everything was "not too sweet" either, which is always perfect in my books. 

for Mimi L,  they carry Banoffee, which is a banana & toffee cream pie ($9).  Other delectable treats include chocolate cream pie ($9), warm apple pie ($9), lemon cheesecake ($10), chocolate souffle ($12), and housemade ice cream or sorbet ($8)

****

SERVICE was impeccable.  Our server, Luigi, was nothing short of accommodating and awesome.  the pseudo "outdoor" seating gave us a great glimpse of St Mark's Square, where performers entertain passerbys.  the festive atmosphere and costume of the performers really enhances the "Venetian" feel.

lastly, love how the manager emails me personally to welcome me back to the restaurant.  i had received a similar email from Wolfgang Puck Bar & Grill at MGM Grand.  great personal touch.  definitely worthy of 5 stars =)  Mr. Puck, i'm starting to become a fan of yours.

Really solid food with a charming atmosphere. Between 7-9pm, we still felt like it was daytime under the bright blue, cloudy sky.

Started with margarita and pepperoni pizzas. The margarita pizza was well seasoned and had delicious cheese. The pepperoni on the pizza was really great as well.

Entree was the stuff quail. It was delicious.

Overall I thought everything was finely executed.

Hubby and I liked this place.
Pizza was plain and simple.... a little drenched in oil but very good.
Porcinni Mushroom raviolli were soooo good.
We had a pitcher of Sangria it was soooooooooo good and cheap $25 bucks for a pretty big pitcher.
There is one thing that I am confused....
Why does  the cafe menu you can eat in and outside where the regular menu you just can eat inside and not outside?
I didn't get that.... wouldn't you think it will be the opposite?

I had dinner here with a large group and its a fun little place in the st marks square area of the Venetian.  The food is basic Italian done really well.  The service as great and the food is tasty.  Ask for a table outside by the square and take advantage of all the entertainment happening in the square.  It is not way over priced like some of the other options near by.

Disclaimer: a vegan's view

I often don't bother reviewing restaurants with poor vegan choices, but feel compelled to here because this one couldn't even get me a salad that was sufficient.

I thought I'd get pizza with no cheese. Their pizza dough has egg in it.

Ok, salad. ALL of their dressings except for one also has egg whites in them. That's odd, but whatever. So I get the chopped vegetable salad with the one dressing they can offer. The salad was mediocre and meager in portion size. So after lunch here I had to go find something to eat.

Never been to a Wolfgang Puck restaurant though I have used a few of his recipes in home cooking before.  I didn't really have super high expectations and I definitely came with a bit of a jaded New Yorker's palate.

The food was good... nothing wrong with any of it.  Service was good, but not great (forgot to bring us bread, forgot orders of water) 

Four of us for lunch, ordered mixed greens, a pizza, burger, and fish.  Nothing was bad, everything was cooked right.  But it seemed a little sterile.  The food didn't "jump"... and for the prices, they should.  The pizza was a bit underdone for this NY pizza-style lover.  It's fine for most on the west coast when black means overdone, but not for me, completely blonde on top means underdone.   Mild leopard-spots on bottom, but no "crispy-ness."
The fries were frozen (not fresh cut), and I highly suspect the dough for the pizza may have not been fresh made either.  Bun for the burger was also suspect.

If you're paying $19 for a burger and fries, everything better be freshly made if possible.  Another reviewer said "best burger"... unfortunately this is pretty far from the truth.  The meat is cooked spot-on... and the overall taste of the red onion marmalade and cheddar was nice... but it was well-beyond Vegas tax.  I could have a similar burger at Island Burger & Shakes in HK for half the price and the same deliciousness.  (Just no frozen tasting fries to pay for)

I was prepared for a bit of "Vegas tax" and "Puck tax" but the food didn't quite justify the extra price for the burger.  It's a decent choice for other fare though.  Shoulda gotten up earlier to make it to Bouchon.  It's probably why there was a bigger line at Enoteca San Marco next door.

I don't think Wolfgang Puck has every did me wrong. He knows how to run a great restaurant even though he isn't there and this place is no exception. I had the gnocchi and also ordered the blue cheese with truffle potato chips to start and it was so salivatingly good. I'm beginning to think Vegas is the new best culinary showcase city.

Really extremely slow bad service. All in one. Our waitress was nice but she never checked up on us. Not even once. I came in a group of 8 people for my birthday dinner. How could you miss us? The food was not good either for contemporary American food. Its definitely not worth writing all the food we got so im just going to keep it real simple. The food took forever in a day dude. I yawned so much i lost my appetite. Then everyone at dinner started to get sleepy.  Wasting my money on food is one thing but wasting my time too? save your time and money for some place else. Next!

This was in my top five favorite places to eat on the strip.  The price and quality were both very fair.  I am giving them 4 stars because this most recent trip to LV they had removed the Fillet Mignon from the menu.  There were also only California Pinot Noirs by the glass.  I prefer the Willamette Valley reds.  I know this is high subjective.  I will be back in the next 2 -3 months and will go back... I hope the Fillet is back.

By far, the best pizza I have ever had.  We liked it so much that we returned to have a different pizza the next day. 

The pizza was light, the crust amazing, and absolutely no grease on the underside of the dough, even after it sat for a bit....the BEST pizza ever. 

Service is amazing.  Order coffee, and watch them refill it before you can even try to finish it. 

Amazing!

This place is all about the atmosphere. It's right next to St. Mark's Square in the Venetian so you can watch the performances while you eat. We came for lunch and I got the hand-cut linguine which was pretty good, the pasta and mussels were nice and fresh. It's was just a little salty. My brother got the lobster club which the waiter said was what they're most famous for. I thought the lobster was over cooked and the bacon over powered the real star, lobster, but my brother loved it and he used to live in Maine. All in all, prices were reasonable and it's convenient if you're staying in the Venetian/Palazzo.

Not a bad place - the food comes out quickly, and they have seating for large groups readily on the outside patio area.

Came here with a group of six, and we were seated and served right away, which was nice. Their hummus and pita bread starters were very good. The pita bread was covered in sprinkled cheese, which was nice.

I ordered the halibut, which came with tiny shrimp, corn, and some beans. Overall the flavor was good, but my halibut was a bit dry. Still tasty though, as I ate the whole thing...

Good service overall, and pleasant restaurant! Good view of all the happenings in the St. Mark's Square.

Firmly squared in st. mark's square is this little restaurant. After all being in "venice" there's no better place to be. There is enterantainment and gelato nearby.

I had the house lasagna, which was pretty good. Nothing ground shaking, but indeed a solid course. Every dish my family ordered was indeed great.

However what stuck out to me, and would make me come back for more was the superb service. My grandparents are super 80+ and the waiter really walked them through and explained the courses to them. Its a nice pleasant touch, and done with the right spirit and its a winner.

I'll kick this off by saying that I just don't care about celebrity chefs, so Wolfgang's name barely registered - I expected good food and hospitality in Vegas, though, and I got it.

My mom reeeally liked this place, so we were here a few of times. The first, we'd taken a red-eye to Vegas and had been up and walking around for 24 hours.- by the time we got to the bar we must've looked like hell, because one of the bartenders rolled right up with big glasses of ice water and told us, "I'm setting you two up for success." Great! We slugged it down and he kept it coming while we sipped our pomegranate martinis - delicious,  nice and minty-tart - and talked Bruins with us.

We stopped for some apps a few days later, since it was there and we were once again pooped from walking around all day, We split a sausage trio (we dubbed it our Las Vegas sausage party) and a pizza with mushrooms, leeks, rosemary and goat cheese. The sausages were varied and prepared just right, with a great complementary set of mustards, and the pizza was savory and heavy on the goat cheese. (A cold slice the next morning was just as great!)

Finally, my mom wanted a real meal here, after admiring the menu so many times over. She had the porcini mushroom ravioli, which I stole a nibble of; it was delicious, cooked just right, and the savory yet fluffy mushroom filling melded really well with the fresh parsley. I had the mesquite grilled salmon with fingerling taters and asparagus. The fish was cooked to a perfect moist medium-rare, and the vegetables in the creamy sauce were fresh and with fluffy-firm potatoes.

We were craving a little gelato - luckily there was a berry-rhubarb cobbler topped with honey gelato on the dessert menu. It arrived piping hot and was flavorful, the crumble full of whole oats and brown sugar and the gelato melting perfectly over the warm fruit. We wanted to sit and rest our poor abused feet after roaming the Mojave all day, so we stuck around and tossed back a few peach bellinis - just delicious.

Service was great, the bartenders skilled and just chatty enough, food was just delicious, and the people-watching is priceless. We kept coming back because every visit was better than the last; Postrio was a high note of our trip!

Went here on a whim, looking for something good and relatively quick to eat. We'd already been to Otto, and the other Italian restaurant in the Square looked overpriced and outdated.
